revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|2011|chess}}
Events in [[chess]] during the year 2011:
== Events ==
=== January === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; margin-left: 1em; float: right;" |+ FIDE January 2011 Top Ten ! Rank !! Prev !! Player !! Rating !! Chng |- | 1 || 2 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Magnus Carlsen]]|NOR}} || 2814 || +12 |- | 2 || 1 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Viswanathan Anand]]|IND}} || 2810 || +6 |- | 3 || 3 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Levon Aronian]]|ARM}} || 2805 || +4 |- | 4 || 4 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vladimir Kramnik]]|RUS}} || 2784 || -7 |- | 5 || 9 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Sergey Karjakin]]|RUS}} || 2776 || +16 |- | 6 || 5 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Veselin Topalov]]|BUL}} || 2775 || -11 |- | 7 || 6 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Alexander Grischuk]]|RUS}} || 2773 || +2 |- | 8 || 8 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]]|AZE}} || 2772 || +9 |- | 9 || 7 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vassily Ivanchuk]]|UKR}} || 2764 || 0 |- | 10 || 15 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Hikaru Nakamura]]|USA}} || 2751 || +10 |} * '''January 1''' - [[Magnus Carlsen]] (NOR) reclaims the top position in the [[FIDE World Rankings|FIDE world rankings]] with an [[Elo rating]] of 2814.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=181 |title=Top 100 Players January 2011 FIDE Top players archive |publisher=Ratings.fide.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> [[Viswanathan Anand]] (IND) falls to second with a rating of 2810. [[Sergey Karjakin]] (RUS) has the greatest rating change among the top 10, improving 16 points from 2760 to 2776. [[Hikaru Nakamura]] (USA) appears in the world top 10 for the first time with a rating of 2751, displacing [[Wang Yue]] (CHN). * '''January 5''' - **[[Deep Sengupta]] (IND) and Arghyadip Das (IND) split first at the [[Hastings International Chess Congress]].<ref name="twic844">{{cite web|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic844.html |title=The Week in Chess 844 |publisher=Theweekinchess.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> **[[Soumya Swaminathan]] (IND) wins the Indian Women's Championship.<ref name="twic844" /> **[[Yannick Pelletier]] (SUI) wins the Basel Hilton Open at the Basel Chess Festival.<ref name="twic844" /> * '''January 6''' - [[Vugar Gashimov]] (AZE) wins the [[Reggio Emilia chess tournament|53rd Reggio Emilia]] tournament with a score of 6/9.<ref name="twic844" /> * '''January 9''' - **[[Alexei Shirov]] (ESP) wins the [[Paul Keres Memorial Tournament]].<ref name="twic844" /> **[[Loek van Wely]] (NED) wins the Berkeley International.<ref name="twic844" /> * '''January 15''' - [[Stewart Haslinger]] (ENG) wins the 36th Seville Open with a score of 7.5/9.<ref name="twic845">{{cite web|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic845.html |title=The Week in Chess 845 |publisher=Theweekinchess.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> * '''January 16''' - [[Alexander Areshchenko]] (UKR) wins the 9th Delhi Parsvnath International Open.<ref name="twic845" /> * '''January 20''' - The free [[chess engine]] [[Houdini (chess)|Houdini]] defeats reigning [[World Computer Chess Championship|world computer chess champion]] [[Rybka (chess)|Rybka]] in the [[Thoresen Chess Engines Competition]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=McClain|first1=Dylan Loeb|title=It Was Houdini Over Rybka in Computer Chess Challenge|url=http://gambit.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/01/22/it-was-houdini-over-rybka-in-computer-chess-challenge/|accessdate=29 August 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=January 22, 2011}}</ref> * '''January 25''' - [[Rafael Leitao]] (BRA) wins the Antonio Rocha Memorial Tournament with a score of 10/11.<ref name="twic847" /> * '''January 26''' - [[Martyn Kravtsiv]] (UKR) wins the 3rd Chennai Open Tournament.<ref name="twic847" /> * '''January 30''' - [[Hikaru Nakamura]] wins the newly renamed<ref>{{cite web|title=Corus Chess Tournament is Tata Steel Chess Tournament|url=http://www.tatasteelchess.com/news/view/id/648/c/Corus_Chess_Tournament_wordt_Tata_Steel_Chess_Tournament|website=tatasteelchess.com|publisher=Corus Chess Press|accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref> [[Tata Steel Chess Tournament|73rd Tata Steel Chess Tournament]] with a score of 9/13, half a point ahead of runner-up [[Viswanathan Anand]].<ref name="twic847">{{cite web|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic847.html |title=The Week in Chess 847 |publisher=Theweekinchess.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> This is Nakamura's first ever win at a super-GM event.<ref name="twic847" /> * '''January 31''' - [[Zhao Zong-Yuan]] (AUS) qualifies for the [[Chess World Cup 2011]] by winning the [[Zonal Tournament|Oceana Zonal]].<ref name="twic847" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newzealandchess.co.nz/Zonal2011/entries.html |title=Oceania Zonal, Rotorua 2011 |publisher=Newzealandchess.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129034607/http://www.newzealandchess.co.nz/Zonal2011/entries.html |archive-date=2016-01-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
=== February === * '''February 3''' - ** [[Vassily Ivanchuk]] wins the [[Gibraltar Chess Festival|Tradewise Gibraltar Chess Festival]] with a score of 9/10.<ref name="twic848">{{cite web|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic848.html |title=The Week in Chess 848 |publisher=Theweekinchess.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> ** Archaeologists discover chess pieces that once belonged to [[James Madison]] at the President's [[Montpelier (Orange, Virginia)|Montpelier]] estate.<ref>{{cite news|title=James Madison chess pieces unearthed at US estate|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8301887/James-Madison-chess-pieces-unearthed-at-US-estate.html|accessdate=29 August 2015|publisher=The Telegraph|date=February 3, 2011}}</ref> * '''February 6''' - [[Atanas Kolev]] (BUL) wins the 33rd Bulgarian Open.<ref name="twic848" /> * '''February 7''' - Vladimir Belous, an untitled 18 year old, takes first place at the Moscow Open.<ref name="twic848" /> * '''February 19''' - [[Le Quang Liem]] (VIE) wins the [[Aeroflot Open|10th Aeroflot Open]] in Moscow.<ref name="twic850">{{cite web|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic850.html |title=The Week in Chess 850 |publisher=Theweekinchess.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> * '''February 22''' - [[Alexei Fedorov]] (BLR) wins the 9th Khazar Cup in Iran.<ref name="twic850" /> * '''February 23''' - [[Gawain Jones]] (ENG) wins the Bunratty Chess Festival.<ref name="twic851">{{cite web|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic851.html |title=The Week in Chess 851 |publisher=Theweekinchess.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref>
=== March === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; margin-left: 1em; float: right;" |+ FIDE March 2011 Top Ten ! Rank !! Prev !! Player !! Rating !! Chng |- | 1 || 2 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Viswanathan Anand]]|IND}} || 2817 || +7 |- | 2 || 1 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Magnus Carlsen]]|NOR}} || 2815 || +1 |- | 3 || 3 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Levon Aronian]]|ARM}} || 2808 || +3 |- | 4 || 4 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vladimir Kramnik]]|RUS}} || 2785 || +1 |- | 5 || 9 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vassily Ivanchuk]]|UKR}} || 2779 || +15 |- | 6 || 5 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Sergey Karjakin]]|RUS}} || 2776 || 0 |- | 7 || 6 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Veselin Topalov]]|BUL}} || 2775 || 0 |- | 8 || 10 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Hikaru Nakamura]]|USA}} || 2774 || +23 |- | 9 || 8 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]]|AZE}} || 2772 || 0 |- | 10 || 7 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Alexander Grischuk]]|RUS}} || 2747 || -26 |} * '''March 1''' - [[Viswanathan Anand]] retakes the top spot in the [[FIDE World Rankings]] with an [[Elo rating]] of 2817.<ref name="FIDEMarch11">{{cite web|url=https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=185 |title=Top 100 Players March 2011 FIDE Top players archive |publisher=Ratings.fide.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> [[Hikaru Nakamura]] has the greatest rating increase, gaining 23 points to reach a rating of 2774.<ref name="FIDEMarch11" /> [[Alexander Grischuk]] (RUS) has the greatest rating decline, losing 26 points and falling to 2747.<ref name="FIDEMarch11" /> * '''March 5''' - [[Humpy Koneru]] (IND) wins the [[FIDE Women's Grand Prix|6th FIDE Women's Grand Prix]] tournament, qualifying for the [[Women's World Chess Championship]] match with [[Hou Yifan]] (CHN).<ref name="twic852">{{cite web|title=The Week in Chess 852|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic852.html#2|website=Theweekinchess.com|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref> * '''March 6''' - [[Jan Smeets]] (NED) wins the 71st [[Daniël Noteboom|Noteboom]] Memorial tournament.<ref name="twic852" /> * '''March 7''' - [[Sergei Tiviakov]] (NED) wins the 19th Fajr Open in [[Iran]].<ref name="twic852" /> * '''March 9''' - [[Gregory Kaidanov]] (USA) wins the Saint Louis Invitational, qualifying for the [[US chess championship|2011 US Championship]].<ref name="twic853">{{cite web|title=The Week in Chess 853|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic853.html|website=Theweekinchess.com|accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref> [[Ray Robson]] (USA) finishes second, also qualifying.<ref name="twic853" /> * '''March 11''' - [[Levon Aronian]] wins the [[Amber chess tournament]] in Monaco.<ref name="twic855">{{cite web|title=The Week in Chess 855|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic855.html|website=Theweekinchess.com|accessdate=5 November 2015}}</ref> * '''March 14''' - [[Irina Chelushkina]] (SRB) wins the 43rd Belgrade Women's International tournament.<ref name="twic853" /> * '''March 16''' - [[Yuriy Kuzubov]] (UKR) wins the [[Reykjavik Open]].<ref name="twic854">{{cite web|title=The Week in Chess 854|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic854.html#4|website=Theweekinchess.com|accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref> * '''March 19''' - The chess team from the [[University of Texas - Dallas]] competes against six invited [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmasters]].<ref name="twic854" /> The GM team wins the match by a score of 42.5-29.5.<ref name="twic854" /> * '''March 27''' - [[Tigran L. Petrosian]] (ARM) wins the 5th George Agzamov Memorial tournament.<ref name="twic855" />
=== April ===
=== May === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; margin-left: 1em; float: right;" |+ FIDE May 2011 Top Ten ! Rank !! Prev !! Player !! Rating !! Chng |- | 1 || 1 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Viswanathan Anand]]|IND}} || 2817 || 0 |- | 2 || 2 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Magnus Carlsen]]|NOR}} || 2815 || 0 |- | 3 || 3 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Levon Aronian]]|ARM}} || 2808 || 0 |- | 4 || 4 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vladimir Kramnik]]|RUS}} || 2785 || 0 |- | 5 || 5 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vassily Ivanchuk]]|UKR}} || 2776 || -3 |- | 6 || 6 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Sergey Karjakin]]|RUS}} || 2776 || 0 |- | 7 || 7 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Veselin Topalov]]|BUL}} || 2775 || 0 |- | 8 || 8 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Hikaru Nakamura]]|USA}} || 2774 || 0 |- | 9 || 9 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]]|AZE}} || 2772 || 0 |- | 10 || 11 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vugar Gashimov]]|AZE}} || 2760 || +14 |} * '''May 1''' - [[Viswanathan Anand]] remains the world number one.<ref name="FIDEMay11">{{cite web|url=https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=189 |title=Top 100 Players May 2011 FIDE Top players archive |publisher=Ratings.fide.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> [[Alexander Grischuk]] falls out of the top 10, and is replaced by [[Vugar Gashimov]] (AZE).<ref name="FIDEMay11" />
=== June ===
{{clear}} === July === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; margin-left: 1em; float: right;" |+ FIDE July 2011 Top Ten ! Rank !! Prev !! Player !! Rating !! Chng |- | 1 || 2 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Magnus Carlsen]]|NOR}} || 2821 || +6 |- | 2 || 1 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Viswanathan Anand]]|IND}} || 2817 || 0 |- | 3 || 3 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Levon Aronian]]|ARM}} || 2805 || -3 |- | 4 || 6 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Sergey Karjakin]]|RUS}} || 2788 || +12 |- | 5 || 4 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vladimir Kramnik]]|RUS}} || 2781 || -4 |- | 6 || 8 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Hikaru Nakamura]]|USA}} || 2770 || -4 |- | 7 || 5 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vassily Ivanchuk]]|UKR}} || 2768 || -8 |- | 8 || 7 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Veselin Topalov]]|BUL}} || 2768 || -7 |- | 9 || 9 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]]|AZE}} || 2765 || -7 |- | 10 || 11 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Ruslan Ponomariov]]|UKR}} || 2764 || +10 |} * '''July 1''' - [[Magnus Carlsen]] is again the world number one.<ref name="FIDEJuly11">{{cite web|url=https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=193 |title=Top 100 Players July 2011 FIDE Top players archive |publisher=Ratings.fide.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> [[Vugar Gashimov]] falls out of the top 10, and is replaced by [[Ruslan Ponomariov]] (UKR).<ref name="FIDEJuly11" />
=== August === {{clear}} === September === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; margin-left: 1em; float: right;" |+ FIDE September 2011 Top Ten ! Rank !! Prev !! Player !! Rating !! Chng |- | 1 || 1 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Magnus Carlsen]]|NOR}} || 2823 || +2 |- | 2 || 2 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Viswanathan Anand]]|IND}} || 2817 || 0 |- | 3 || 3 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Levon Aronian]]|ARM}} || 2807 || +2 |- | 4 || 5 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vladimir Kramnik]]|RUS}} || 2791 || +10 |- | 5 || 4 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Sergey Karjakin]]|RUS}} || 2772 || -16 |- | 6 || 8 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Veselin Topalov]]|BUL}} || 2768 || 0 |- | 7 || 7 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vassily Ivanchuk]]|UKR}} || 2765 || -3 |- | 8 || 10 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Ruslan Ponomariov]]|UKR}} || 2758 || -6 |- | 9 || 13 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Alexander Grischuk]]|RUS}} || 2757 || +9 |- | 10 || 15 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Gata Kamsky]]|USA}} || 2756 || +15 |} * '''September 1''' - [[Magnus Carlsen]] remains the world number one.<ref name="FIDESep11">{{cite web|url=https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=197 |title=Top 100 Players September 2011 FIDE Top players archive |publisher=Ratings.fide.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> [[Hikaru Nakamura]] and [[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]] fall out of the top 10, and are replaced by [[Alexander Grischuk]] and [[Gata Kamsky]] (USA).<ref name="FIDESep11" />
=== October === {{clear}} === November === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; margin-left: 1em; float: right;" |+ FIDE November 2011 Top Ten ! Rank !! Prev !! Player !! Rating !! Chng |- | 1 || 1 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Magnus Carlsen]]|NOR}} || 2826 || +3 |- | 2 || 2 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Viswanathan Anand]]|IND}} || 2811 || -6 |- | 3 || 3 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Levon Aronian]]|ARM}} || 2802 || -5 |- | 4 || 4 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vladimir Kramnik]]|RUS}} || 2800 || +9 |- | 5 || 13 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Teimour Radjabov]]|AZE}} || 2781 || +29 |- | 6 || 7 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vassily Ivanchuk]]|UKR}} || 2775 || +10 |- | 7 || 6 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Veselin Topalov]]|BUL}} || 2768 || 0 |- | 8 || 5 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Sergey Karjakin]]|RUS}} || 2763 || -9 |- | 9 || 17 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Alexander Morozevich]]|RUS}} || 2762 || +25 |- | 10 || 12 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Hikaru Nakamura]]|USA}} || 2758 || +5 |} * '''November 1''' - [[Magnus Carlsen]] is again the world number one.<ref name="FIDENov11">{{cite web|url=https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=201 |title=Top 100 Players November 2011 FIDE Top players archive |publisher=Ratings.fide.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref> [[Teimour Radjabov]] (AZE) surges from 13th to 5th with a ratings gain of 29 points.<ref name="FIDENov11" /> [[Alexander Morozevich]] (RUS) also makes a big leap, going from 17th to 9th with a ratings gain of 25 points.<ref name="FIDENov11" /> [[Hikaru Nakamura]] reenters the top 10.<ref name="FIDENov11" /> [[Ruslan Ponomariov]], [[Alexander Grischuk]], and [[Gata Kamsky]] fall out of the top 10.<ref name="FIDENov11" />
=== December === {{clear}}
==National champions==
===Armenia=== * '''Men's''' - [[Robert Hovhannisyan]]<ref name="twic847" /> * '''Women's''' - [[Siranush Andriasian]]<ref name="twic846">{{cite web|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic846.html |title=The Week in Chess 846 |publisher=Theweekinchess.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref>
===Azerbaijan=== * '''Men's''' - [[Nidjat Mamedov]]<ref name="twic848" />
===Belarus=== * '''Men's''' - Andrey Zhigalko<ref name="twic847" /> * '''Women's''' - [[Anna Sharevich]]<ref name="twic849">{{cite web|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic849.html |title=The Week in Chess 849 |publisher=Theweekinchess.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-30}}</ref>
===Bulgaria=== * '''Women's''' - Darena Sikova<ref name="twic850" />
===Chile=== * '''Men's''' - Alvaro Valdes Escobar<ref name="twic851" />
===Croatia=== * '''Men's''' - [[Ante Brkic]]<ref name="twic847" /> * '''Women's''' - Borka Franciskovic<ref name="twic848" />
===Georgia=== * '''Women's''' - [[Maia Lomineishvili]]<ref name="twic846" />
===Poland=== * '''Men's''' - [[Mateusz Bartel]]<ref name="twic850" /> * '''Women's''' - Jolante Zawadzka<ref name="twic850" />
===Romania=== * '''Men's''' - [[Constantin Lupulescu]]<ref name="twic851" /> * '''Women's''' - [[Cristina Adela Foisor]]<ref name="twic851" />
===Serbia=== * '''Men's''' - [[Ivan Ivanisevic]]<ref name="twic853" />
===Turkey=== * '''Men's''' - [[Emre Can]]<ref name="twic849" />
===United States=== * '''Men's''' - [[Gata Kamsky]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Klein|first1=Mike|title=Kamsky Reigns Supreme, Women Head to Tiebreak|url=http://saintlouischessclub.org/news/2011-04-28/kamsky-reigns-supreme-women-head-tiebreak|accessdate=30 August 2015|publisher=St. Louis Chess Club & Scholastic Center|date=April 28, 2011}}</ref> * '''Women's''' - [[Anna Zatonskih]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ungar-Sargon|first1=Batya|title=A Passionate Rivalry Between Two Women - On the Chess Board and Everywhere Else|url=http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-news-and-politics/150595/chess-rivalry-jewish-women|accessdate=30 August 2015|publisher=Tablet Magazine|date=October 30, 2013}}</ref>
==Deaths== * '''February 12''' - [[Mato Damjanovic]], Croatian and Yugoslav [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]], dies at the age of 83.<ref name="twic849" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Grandmaster Mato Damjanovic dies at 83|url=http://www.chessvibes.com/?q=reports/grandmaster-mato-damjanovic-dies-at-83|publisher=Chess Vibes|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref>

page.title: 2016 BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award

revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = 2016 BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award | date = 18 December 2016 | location = [[Genting Arena]], [[Birmingham, UK|Birmingham]] | country = United Kingdom | presenter = [[British Broadcasting Corporation]] (BBC) | host = [[Gary Lineker]]
[[Clare Balding]]
[[Gabby Logan]] | winner = | website = {{url|https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/sports-personality/}} | network = {{Unbulleted list|[[BBC One]]|[[BBC One HD]]|[[BBC Radio 5 Live]]}} | runtime = 140 minutes | previous = [[2015 BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award|2015]] | main = [[BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award]] | next = [[2017 BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award|2017]] }} The '''2016 BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award''' took place on 18 December 2016 at the [[Genting Arena]] in Birmingham. It was the 63rd presentation of the [[BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award]]. Awarded annually by the [[British Broadcasting Corporation]] (BBC), the main award honours an individual's [[Sport in the United Kingdom|British sporting achievement]] over the past year, with the winner selected by public vote from a sixteen-person shortlist; the winner was Tennis player [[Andy Murray]], who became the first person to win the award three times.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38358869|title=BBC Sports Personality of the Year 2016: Andy Murray wins for a record third time|work=BBC Sport |date=18 December 2016 |accessdate=18 December 2016}}{{citeweb|url= https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/dec/18/andy-murray-wins-bbc-sports-personality-of-the-year-2016|title=Andy Murray wins BBC Sports Personality of the Year 2016 award|date=19 December 2016|work=Guardian|accessdate=20 December 2016}} The event, broadcast live on [[BBC One]], was hosted by [[Gary Lineker]], [[Clare Balding]] and [[Gabby Logan]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/36637729 |title=BBC Sports Personality of the Year 2016 in Birmingham |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |accessdate=2016-11-28}} ==Nominees== The nominees were revealed on 28 November 2016, during BBC One's ''[[The One Show]]''. To reflect the vast success of the past year, a record 16 sportspeople were named on the shortlist.{{Cite web|title = BBC Sports Personality of the Year 2016: Shortlist of 16 revealed for award|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38128821|website = BBC Sport|accessdate = 28 November 2016}}{{citeweb|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/nov/28/andy-murray-heads-spoty-list-but-there-is-no-place-for-chris-froome-and-others|title=Andy Murray heads Spoty list but no place for Chris Froome and others|date=28 November 2016|work=Guardian |accessdate=9 December 2016}} {{Clear}} {| class="wikitable" !Nominee !Sport !2016 Achievement !BBC profile ! Votes (percentage) |- style="font-weight:bold; background:gold;" |[[Andy Murray]] |Tennis |Won his second singles [[2016 Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon]] title, reached the singles finals of both the [[2016 Australian Open|Australian Open]] and [[2016 French Open|French Open]], defended his singles title at the [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Olympics]] (the first player ever to do so), won the year-ending [[2016 ATP World Tour Finals|World Tour Finals]] and became the first ever Briton to top the computerised [[List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players|ATP singles rankings]]. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38135223] | 247,419 (33.1%) |- style="background:silver;" |[[Alistair Brownlee]] |Triathlon |Won a second successive [[Triathlon at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Olympic]] title in the men's triathlon, thus becoming the first competitor (man or woman) in Olympic history to defend the triathlon title. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38133042] | 121,665 (16.3%) |- style="background:tan;" |[[Nick Skelton]] |Equestrian |Won the [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Olympic]] individual show jumping competition at the age of 58, thus becoming the oldest champion in Olympic equestrian history and the oldest British Olympic champion in 108 years. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38135226] | 109,197 (14.6%) |- |[[Mo Farah]] |Athletics |Became the first athlete in 40 years to achieve the long distance "double-double" (5,000 / 10,000 metres) at the [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Olympics]]. Also became the first athlete to win nine global outdoor long-distance titles on the track, both consecutively and outright. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38134244] | 54,476 (7.3%) |- |[[Sophie Christiansen]] |Equestrian |Won a clean sweep of three gold medals in para-dressage (team championship and championship / freestyle test grade Ia) at the [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|Paralympics]], the second successive Games in which she achieved the feat. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38134242] | 37,284 (5.0%) |- |[[Kate Richardson-Walsh]] |Hockey |Captained the Great Britain team to a first ever gold medal in the women's [[Field hockey at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Olympic]] field hockey tournament, winning every single match. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38135225] | 34,604 (4.6%) |- |[[Max Whitlock]] |Gymnastics |Became the first ever British Olympic champion in [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|gymnastics]], winning two gold medals (floor exercise and pommel horse) within two hours, as well as his country's first individual all-around medal (bronze) in 108 years. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38138032] | 32,858 (4.4%) |- |[[Laura Trott|Laura Kenny]] |Cycling |Won two [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Olympic]] titles in track cycling (team pursuit and omnium, both of which were successful defenses); in doing so, she became the first female British Olympian and only the second female Olympic cyclist (after [[Leontien van Moorsel]]) to win four gold medals. Also won scratch and omnium gold at the [[2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships|UCI Track World Championships]]. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38134246] | 31,781 (4.3%) |- |[[Jamie Vardy]] |Football |Helped [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] win the [[Premier League]] title, having been given odds of 5,000-1 to do so at the beginning of the season. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38135228] | 25,020 (3.3%) |- |[[Jason Kenny]] |Cycling |Won three [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Olympic]] titles in track cycling (team sprint, sprint and keirin; the first two were also successful defenses); in doing so, he matched [[Chris Hoy|Sir Chris Hoy's]] hat-trick from 2008 and his records for the most gold medals (6) won by a British Olympian and an Olympic cyclist. Also won sprint gold at the [[2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships – Men's sprint|UCI Track World Championships]]. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38134245] | 12,376 (1.7%) |- |[[Adam Peaty]] |Swimming |Won the men's 100 metre breaststroke (and set two world records en-route) to become Great Britain's first male [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Olympic]] swimming champion since [[Adrian Moorhouse]] 28 years prior. Also part of the silver medal winning team in the 4 x 100 metres medley relay event, the country's highest finish in the event. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38135224] | 11,129 (1.5%) |- |[[Gareth Bale]] |Football |Won the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] (for a second time) with [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and was part of the [[Wales national football team|Wales]] team that reached the semi-finals of [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]]. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38133041] | 10,786 (1.4%) |- |[[Nicola Adams]] |Boxing |Successfully defended her flyweight boxing title at the [[Boxing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Olympics]], thus becoming the first British boxer in 92 years to do so in any division. She also won flyweight gold in the [[2016 AIBA Women's World Boxing Championships|AIBA Women's World Championships]] and achieved the career 'grand slam' of Olympic, World, European and Commonwealth titles. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38133040] | 7,812 (1.0%) |- |[[Kadeena Cox]] |Athletics/Cycling |Became the first British Paralympian to win medals in two different sports at a single Games in 28 years, with one gold in [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|cycling]] (C4-5 500m time trial) as well as a medal of each colour (gold, silver and bronze) in [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|athletics]] (T38 400m, T35-38 4 × 100 m relay and T38 100m respectively). |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38134243] | 5,574 (0.7%) |- |[[Sarah Storey|Dame Sarah Storey]] |Cycling |Successfully defended three [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|Paralympic]] titles in cycling (C4-5 road race and C5 time trial / individual pursuit) to become the most successful British Paralympian in the modern era, and the most successful British female Paralympian of all time (with a total of 14 gold medals). |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38135227] | 3,580 (0.5%) |- |[[Danny Willett]] |Golf |Won the [[2016 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]], thus becoming only the second English golfer (after [[Nick Faldo]]) to achieve such a feat. |[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/sports-personality/38138033] | 2,227 (0.3%) |- |} ==Other awards== In addition to the main award as "Sports Personality of the Year", several other awards were also announced: *[[BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year]]: [[Simone Biles]] *[[BBC Sports Personality Team of the Year Award]]: [[Leicester City F.C.]] *[[BBC Sports Personality of the Year Lifetime Achievement Award]]: [[Michael Phelps]] *[[BBC Sports Personality of the Year Coach Award]]: [[Claudio Ranieri]] *[[BBC Sports Personality of the Year Helen Rollason Award]]: Ben Smith *[[BBC Young Sports Personality of the Year]]: [[Eleanor Robinson (swimmer)|Ellie Robinson]] *[[BBC Sports Unsung Hero Award]]: Marcellus Baz ==References== {{for|the new stadium|Alex Box Stadium, Skip Bertman Field}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Alex Box Stadium | nickname = | image = [[File:Alex Box Stadium Baton Rouge Louisiana.jpg|250px|''The Intimidator'' behind the right field fence in Alex Box Stadium. Photograph – June 3, 2005.]] | location = Skip Bertman Drive
[[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] 70803
{{flag|United States}}| | broke_ground = | opened = March 12, 1938 | coordinates = {{Coord|30.4121|-91.1877|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | closed = 2008 | demolished = 2010 | owner = [[Louisiana State University]] | operator = LSU Athletics Department | surface = natural grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = LSU Diamond or LSU Varsity Baseball Field (1938–1943) | tenants = [[Louisiana State University]] [[baseball]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1938–2008)
[[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] ([[National League|NL]]) (spring training) (1938–1939) | seating_capacity = 7,760 | dimensions = Foul Lines: 330 ft.
Power Alleys: 365 ft.
Center Field: 405 ft.
Outfield Fence Height: 10 ft.
Center Field Fence Height: 15 ft.}} '''Alex Box Stadium''', sometimes pronounced as "Elec" or "Alec" Box[http://www.2theadvocate.com/sports/lsu/baseballblog/18839889.html 2theadvocate.com | LSU Baseball Blog | Alex? Alec? or Elec? — Baton Rouge, Louisiana] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719191607/http://www.2theadvocate.com/sports/lsu/baseballblog/18839889.html |date=July 19, 2008 }} was a [[baseball]] [[stadium]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]], United States. It was the home field of the [[LSU Tigers baseball]] team. The stadium was located across the street from [[Tiger Stadium (LSU)|Tiger Stadium]], which is visible in right field. It was most notable for ''The Intimidator'', a large billboard behind the right-field fence featuring the five years in which LSU won the [[College World Series]]. The stadium opened in 1938 and closed in 2008. It was replaced with a new stadium 200 yards to the south named [[Alex Box Stadium, Skip Bertman Field]]. Both structures were named for Simeon Alex Box, an LSU letterman (1942) who was killed in North Africa during World War II. The stadium was called LSU Diamond or LSU Varsity Baseball Field when it first opened. The [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] held spring training at the ballpark in 1938 and 1939. The Giants played the first baseball game at the park, defeating the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] 6-5. The first LSU game was March 21, 1938. LSU led Minnesota, 4-2, after three innings when the game was halted due to rain. The first official LSU Game at the stadium was March 24, 1938 when Minnesota defeated LSU, 6-5.[http://www.lsusports.net/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=5200&ATCLID=177194 LSU Baseball Facilities – LSUsports.net – The Official Web Site of LSU Tigers Athletics] The final regular season series at Alex Box Stadium was played between LSU and [[Mississippi State University]].[http://www.lsusports.net/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=27865&SPID=2173&DB_OEM_ID=5200&ATCLID=1467715 Storylines Aplenty as Baseball Plays Final Series at Alex Box – LSUsports.net—The Official Web Site of LSU Tigers Athletics] At the time, it appeared this would be the last series ever at Alex Box Stadium; however, LSU was selected to host a regional in the NCAA Tournament (which it won), and subsequently hosted a [[Super Regional]] as the #7 national seed.[http://www.lsusports.net/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=5200&ATCLID=1474516 Baseball Earns No. 7 National Seed, Faces TSU – LSUsports.net—The Official Web Site of LSU Tigers Athletics] It appeared that Alex Box stadium would close on a sour note for the Tigers, as LSU dropped Game 1 to [[UC Irvine]] 11-5, and in Game 2, LSU was three outs away from elimination, trailing 7-4 in the ninth inning. However, UC Irvine was unable to close out the LSU Tigers and LSU came from behind to win the game 9-7.[https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/baseball/2008-06-08-lsu-urvine_N.htm LSU beats UC Irvine 9-7 to stay alive – USATODAY.com] The stadium was thus given one final chance to close on a high note, which it did in Game 3 of the Super Regional played on June 9, 2008, as LSU defeated UC Irvine 21-7. As a result of the victory, LSU won the Baton Rouge Super Regional two games to one and advanced to the [[College World Series]] in [[Omaha, Nebraska]]. In the final play at the stadium, [[Tyler Hoechlin]] hit a grounder to pitcher Anthony Ranaudo, who threw to first baseman Buzzy Haydel for the final out.[http://www.2theadvocate.com/sports/lsu/19704714.html?index=14&c=y Some "lasts" at Alex Box Stadium] The stadium has been dismantled and sold to fans. == Tournaments Hosted == [[File:Left Field Lunatics.JPG|left|thumbnail|LSU fans enjoyed one final regional in Alex Box Stadium during the 2008 NCAA tournament.]] '''NCAA Regional Tournaments''' (18): 1986, 1990, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2008
'''NCAA Super Regional Series''' (4): 2000, 2003, 2004, 2008
'''SEC Tournaments''' (4): 1985, 1986, 1991, 1993
'''ABCA Hall of Fame Tournament''' (1): 1991

{{Infobox football league | logo = | pixels = 200 | country = {{BLR}} | confed = [[UEFA]] | founded = 1985 | divisions = 1 | teams = 6 | relegation = | levels = 1 | domest_cup = [[Belarusian Women's Cup]] | confed_cup = [[UEFA Women's Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] | champions = [[FC Minsk (women)|FC Minsk]] (5th title) | season = 2017 | most successful club = [[Babruichanka Babruisk]] (12 titles) | website = [http://www.bff.by/sorev/jenskie/ BFF] | current = [[2017 Belarusian Premier League (women)|2017]] }} The '''Belarusian Premier League''' is the top level women's [[Association football|football]] league of Belarus. The champion of the league qualifies for a spot in the [[UEFA Women's Champions League]]. ==Format== In 2009 teams in the league played each other twice. In the 2010 season the teams play each other three times. In 2008 there were two playoff groups after the regular season. Teams 1 to 4 and 5 to 8 played a double round robin (so 6 additional matches). ==Teams== The 2011 season is made up by the following teams. {{Location map+|Belarus|width=350| |alt=Map of Belarus and the twelve teams of the 2011 Premier League |caption=Locations of teams in the 2011 Belarusian Premier League |places= {{Location map~|Belarus|lat_deg=53|lat_min=09|lon_deg=29|lon_min=14|position=right|label=Bobruisk}} {{Location map~|Belarus|lat_deg=52|lat_min=08|lon_deg=23|lon_min=40|position=right|label=Brest}} {{Location map~|Belarus|lat_deg=53|lat_min=54|lon_deg=27|lon_min=34|position=left|label=Minsk}} {{Location map~|Belarus|lat_deg=53|lat_min=54|lon_deg=30|lon_min=20|position=right|label=Mogilev}} {{Location map~|Belarus|lat_deg=52|lat_min=27|lon_deg=30|lon_min=59|position=left|label=Gomel}} {{Location map~|Belarus|lat_deg=53|lat_min=40|lon_deg=23|lon_min=50|position=right|label=Grodno}} {{Location map~|Belarus|lat_deg=55|lat_min=11|lon_deg=30|lon_min=10|position=left|label=Vitebsk}} {{Location map~|Belarus|lat_deg=54|lat_min=19|lon_deg=26|lon_min=51|position=right|label=Molodechno}} {{Location map~|Belarus|lat_deg=54|lat_min=09|lon_deg=25|lon_min=19|position=right|label=Voronovo}} }} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Replacing [[File:AdamMatthews balloonglow 09242005.jpg]] with Commons version [[File:פסטיבל כדורים פורחים בלוגראס בלילה.jpg]] ([[User talk:Magog the Ogre|report errors here]])
revision.text:
[[File:פסטיבל הכדורים הפורחים בלוגראס.jpg|300px|thumb|right|Hot air balloons launching during the balloon race at the Adam Matthews Balloon Festival.]]
The '''Bluegrass Balloon Festival''', formerly called the '''Adam Matthews Balloon Festival''', was the fifth largest [[hot air balloon festival]] in the [[United States]], and the largest in the state of [[Kentucky]]. From 1999 to 2009, it was held annually in late September at [[Bowman Field (airport)|Bowman Field]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky]].
The festival features up to 100 hot air balloons participating in three early morning balloon races and two evening balloon glows. Other events include four live concerts, 11 free children's activities, and a car show featuring more than 150 classic, exotic, and modified cars. There is also a balloon education center teaching the fundamentals of ballooning, as well as food, a beer garden, and other activities. It is common to have crowds of more than 100,000 on the busiest day of the festival. Many events are held during the three days. One of the more popular attractions is the evening balloon glow, when balloons are inflated and glow to music after dark. Another is the early morning balloon race with a cash prize for the winner.
The Adam Matthews Balloon Festival celebrated its last festival in September 2006. The festival was purchased by The Spirit of Kentucky Foundation and was renamed the Bluegrass Balloon Festival.
==History== [[File:פסטיבל כדורים פורחים בלוגראס בלילה.jpg|300px|right|thumb|Hot air balloons light up for an evening balloon glow at the Adam Matthews Balloon Festival.]]
For many years, local pilots gathered to give back to the community by holding a year-end balloon glow at Bowman Field. When the local event was canceled due to the lack of funds, Adam Burckle, the founder of the Adam Matthews Cheesecake Company, came up with an idea that led to the festival.
The first year event was held with 52 balloons in attendance. Many balloons were local, although some pilots traveled from far across the United States. The initial event raised $20,000 for the Dream Factory, an organization that helps grant wishes to children with life-threatening diseases.
The second annual event was held in 2000 with 70 balloons from across the country. The event became so popular that the entry was limited to 70 balloons and there was a waiting list.
The events of the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] on [[New York City]] and [[Washington, D.C.]] put some doubt into the flights of the festival, as civil aviation flights (including ballooning) were restricted for a period of time after the attacks. The festival petitioned the [[National Safety Council]] and the [[Federal Aviation Administration|FAA]] to allow the flight of hot air balloons, which was approved only two days before the festival. Approximately 75 balloons attended the event that year, making it the largest balloon festival held in Kentucky's history.
By 2002, the event had grown to 85 registered balloons, and [[WHAS-TV]] 11, a local [[television station]] in Louisville, featured the evening Balloon Glow during its prime time broadcast. [[Meijer]]s sponsored the Starship Concert, and Dean's Milk sponsored the balloon races with more than $27,500 in prize money. Pilots travelled from as far as away as [[New Zealand]], [[Canada]] and the Western U.S.; they raised more than $35,000 for the [[Make-A-Wish Foundation]], the [[Louisville Zoo]], and the [[WHAS Crusade for Children|Crusade for Children]].
By 2003, the festival had grown to 100 registered balloons, with more than $40,000 in prizes awarded. There was also six hours of live TV coverage, and more than 120,000 people attended the event over three days. Portions of the parking fees benefited the [[WHAS Crusade for Children|Crusade for Children]], and additional funds were raised for the [[Louisville Zoo]] and several other local non-profit groups.
In 2007 the Adam Matthews Balloon Festival was purchased by the Spirit of Kentucky Foundation for $1, and the event was renamed the Bluegrass Balloon Festival. It continued to be the largest ballooning event in Kentucky and the fifth largest in the United States.
The festival was cancelled in 2010 for various reasons.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20101231175930/http://www.bluegrassballoons.com/</ref> It was to return in 2011 with a new name, "Spirit of Kentucky Balloon Festival", but that was cancelled as well.<ref>https://www.facebook.com/SpiritofKYBalloonFestival/posts/283291378353039</ref> There has been no sign of the existence of the festival since that time.
==See also== * [[List of attractions and events in the Louisville metropolitan area]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use British English|date=March 2018}} [[File:CrickBoatShow.jpg|thumb|right|Crick Boat Show]] The '''Crick Boat Show''' & Waterways Festival is an event that has been held annually at Crick Marina in Northamptonshire, England, since its inception in 2000.
==Location== The show takes place every year on the [[Grand Union Canal]] at Crick Marina. This is located on the Leicester Line, to the north of Crick Tunnel, on the level section of canal between the tops of the [[Watford Locks|Watford flight]] and the [[Foxton Locks|Foxton flight]]. The site is close to junction 18 on the [[M1 motorway|M1]], and the event has traditionally taken place on the last bank holiday weekend in May.<ref>{{harvnb |Cumberlidge |2009 |p=140}}</ref>
==Facilities== The show was first held in 2000,<ref>Waterways World, June 2000</ref> when it was organised by [[British Waterways]], and has been held every year since then. Responsibility for its organisation was passed to Waterways World Magazine in 2011, where it has remained ever since in partnership with the [[Canal & River Trust]] and Crick Marina.
The event is the focal point of the inland boating calendar and provides the opportunity for boat-builders and sellers to promote new and second-hand boats to visitors considering buying a boat. Every conceivable type of product and service for canal boats is represented by the exhibitors, ranging from equipment to finance and insurance. In a dedicated lecture theatre, a series of free seminars are held throughout the event, covering such topics as boat maintenance, living afloat and boat-buying on a budget.
Free boat-trips along the Grand Union Canal are provided – but must be booked upon arrival at the show – and boat-handling courses are available for an additional fee.<ref>Waterways World, May 2018</ref>
The event is also billed as a 'Waterways Festival', with continuous live music, a large beer festival (organised by The Wheatsheaf public house from the local village) with up to 40 real ales, food and crafts stalls and a range of children's activities broadening its appeal. The live music has included headline performances by recording artists such as Toyah Wilcox (2014), Hazel O’Connor (2015) and Tom Robinson (2016). But also features well-known tribute acts such as T-Rextasy (2017) and Abba Revival (2018).
The 2017 show was attended by 27,000-plus people <ref>Waterways World, August 2017</ref> and included around 40 'boats on show' among nearly 200 exhibitors.
==Favourite Boat in Show Award== A well established tradition of the event is the 'Favourite Boat in Show' award, which is voted for by show visitors and presented to the winner on the Monday. In 2017 the scheme was updated to include separate categories for narrowboats and wide-beam craft. The winner of that year's 'Favourite Narrowboat in Show' was Bourne Boat Builders with its 60 ft luxury craft, ''Threpence Ha'penny,'' while Elton Moss Boatbuilders was presented with the 'Favourite Wide-beam in Show' accolade for its 65 ft by 12 ft Kingsley Barge.<ref>Waterways World, August 2017</ref>
Previous winners are as follows:
2016 Boating Leisure Services – ''Silver Melody'': a 58 ft semi-trad narrowboat with a bright interior.<ref>Waterways World, August 2016</ref>
2015 Boating Leisure Services – ''Columbus'': a 60 ft Josher tug-style traditional narrowboat with an oak interior.<ref>Waterways World, August 2015</ref>
2014 Boating Leisure Services – ''Shackleton'': a 58 ft semi-trad narrowboat contrasting a fairly traditional exterior with a bright modern interior.<ref>Waterways World, August 2014</ref>
2013 Navigations Narrowboats – ''Emily'': a 58 ft tug-style narrowboat with a Tyler Wilson shell.<ref>Waterways World, July 2013</ref>
2012 MGM Boats – ''Snail’s Pace:'' a 58 ft cruiser-stern, reverse layout narrowboat that had been custom built for its owners.<ref>Waterways World, August 2012</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|UK Waterways}} *[[Canals of the United Kingdom]] *[[History of the British canal system]]
