revision.text:
[[Association football]] (also known as soccer) is the most popular sport in almost all [[Africa|African]] countries, and in 2010 [[South Africa]] became the first African nation to host the [[FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/06/150624110200.htm |title=Women's sport participation and gender equality: African women in the beautiful game|accessdate=February 18, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160214065238/https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/06/150624110200.htm |archivedate=February 14, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=127600200 |title=The History Of Soccer In Africa |publisher=NPR.org |date=2010-06-09 |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ccxEAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA219 |title=Africa, Football and FIFA: Politics, Colonialism and Resistance - Paul Darby - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KKlSSRq-P2QC&pg=PA3 |title=Sports and Games of the Ancients - Steve Craig - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.one.org/us/2016/08/16/12-things-you-didnt-know-about-sports-in-africa/|title=12 things you didn't know about sports in Africa|date=16 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.revolutionsports.co.uk/news/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/SMGI-Middle-East-North-Africa-Report-180911final.pdf |format=PDF |title=Popularity and Participation of Sports in the Middle East and North Africa |website=Revolutionsports.co.uk |accessdate=2016-08-26}}</ref>
Some African nations, like [[Kenya]] and [[Ethiopia]], are very dominant at long distance running, whilst north African countries such [[Algeria]], [[Egypt]] and [[Tunisia]] are dominant in [[handball]], and countries such as Zimbabwe. Rugby and golf are reasonably popular in a few [[Africa|African countries]], though rugby is very popular in South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/21/southafrica-sport-divided-race |title=South African sport still divided by race | World news |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref> African lack of success in international sports is due to lack of infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web|last=Powell |first=Anita |url=http://www.theroot.com/articles/world/2012/08/african_countries_olympic_medals_seem_elusive.html |title=African Countries: Olympic Medals Seem Elusive |publisher=Theroot.com |date=2012-08-12 |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Baker|editor1-first = William J.|editor2-last = Mangan|editor2-first= James A. |title = Sport in Africa: essays in social history|location = New York|publisher = Africana Publishing Company|date= 1987|isbn= 0841909067|oclc = 15107411}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/13/opinion/olympics-african-village/ |title=Olympics: Why Africa fell by the wayside |publisher=CNN.com |date=2012-08-14 |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Djanie |first=Akua |url=http://newafricanmagazine.com/why-did-africa-come-to-the-london-olympics/ |title=Why Did Africa Come To The London Olympics? |publisher=Newafricanmagazine.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Edwards |first=Piers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-36150984 |title=Own goal? Africa's shambolic sports management |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pambazuka.org/global-south/sports-africa-untapped-resource-development |title=Sports in Africa: An untapped resource for development | Pambazuka News |website=Pambazuka.org |date= |accessdate=2016-08-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://theconversation.com/why-africas-sports-industry-needs-to-step-up-to-the-plate-43144|title=Why Africa's sports industry needs to step up to the plate|first=Simon|last=Chadwick|publisher=|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.econrsa.org/papers/w_papers/wp162.pdf |format=PDF |title=An Economic Analysis of Sports Performance in Africa |author1=John Luiz |author2=Riyas Fadal |website=Econrsa.org |accessdate=2016-08-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/news/pressrelease/transparency_internationals_global_corruption_report_sport_highlights_scale|title=Press release - Transparency International Global Corruption Report: Sport highlights scale of corruption in Africa|first=Transparency International|last=e.V.|publisher=|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref>
==Team sports== ===Basketball=== {{main article|Basketball in Africa}} [[Basketball]] is also popular throughout the continent, with notable results in Nigeria, Tunisia, Egypt, Senegal, Ivory Coast, Cameroon and Angola.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/24/sport/nba-shoots-for-african-basketball/ |title=NBA shoots for African basketball stars, courts new fan base - CNN.com |website=Edition.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/2015/news/features/shaun_powell/07/30/hakeem-olajuwon-godfather-of-basketball-in-africa/ |title=Olajuwon: Godfather of basketball in Africa |website=NBA.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Tunde Eludini |url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/sports/sports-features/202664-interview-africa-basketball-league-surpassing-expectations-ceo.html |title=INTERVIEW: Africa Basketball League surpassing expectations – CEO - Premium Times Nigeria |website=Premiumtimesng.com |date=2016-04-30 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/nba/story/_/id/13354356/nba-africa-game-symbol-hope |title=NBA Africa Game a symbol of hope |website=Espn.co.uk |date=2015-07-31 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Willens |first=Max |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/africa-nba-will-broadcast-more-500-games-tv-broadband-mobile-next-season-through-2357200 |title=In Africa, NBA Will Broadcast More Than 500 Games On TV, Broadband And Mobile Next Season Through Econet Partnership |website=Ibtimes.com |date=2015-08-01 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2015/07/30/basketball-without-borders-africa-luol-deng-masai-ujiri-chris-paul-exhibition-game/30903465/ |title=NBA helping basketball grow in Africa with grassroots efforts |website=Usatoday.com |date=2015-08-01 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Richman |url=http://www.voanews.com/content/mandela-instrumental-popularizing-basketball-africa/1812584.html |title=Mandela Instrumental in Popularizing Basketball in Africa |website=Voanews.com |date=2013-12-18 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref>
===Cricket=== [[Cricket]] is a popular summer sport in the United Kingdom and has been exported to other parts of the former [[British Empire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=844-DwAAQBAJ&pg=PT60&lpg=PT60&dq=cricket+in+ghana+history&source=bl&ots=SK24q0Detq&sig=foYJvz2ciO4-LX6kXKDiaKch2_E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj6w7f15avYAhUJJ1AKHXM5Cxs4ChDoAQhGMAY#v=onepage&q=cricket+in+ghana+history&f=false|title=Cricket: A Political History of the Global Game, 1945-2017: 1945 to 2012|first=Stephen|last=Wagg|date=14 November 2017|publisher=Routledge|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name=Duncan>{{cite book|title=Skirting the Boundary: A History of Women's Cricket|first=Isabelle|last=Duncan|location=London|publisher=Robson Press|year=2013|isbn=9781849545464}}</ref><ref name=Aglietti>{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/rwanda-cricket-growing-game-hope-064714133--spt.html|title=Rwanda cricket, growing a game of hope|first=Stephanie|last=Aglietti|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Yahoo Sports|date=11 September 2014|accessdate=8 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20798480 |title=Why cricket is gaining in popularity in Rwanda |publisher=BBC News |date=2012-12-24 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=11422614 |title=Cricket World Cup: How the South African media reacted to the Black Caps' win - Sport - NZ Herald News |publisher=Nzherald.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-31944995 |title=The Nigerians bowled over by cricket - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2015-03-22 |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref> [[Cricket]] has its origins in south east Britain. It is popular throughout England and Wales, and parts of the Netherlands, and in other world areas, especially in southern [[Africa]], [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and the [[Indian subcontinent]]. It is played to [[test cricket]] level in South Africa and Zimbabwe, with notable results in Kenya and Namibia.
===Football=== {{main article|Women's football in Africa}} {{main article|Football in Africa}} [[Association football]] (also known as soccer) is the most popular sport in almost all African countries. African club teams compete in the [[CAF Champions League]] and [[CAF Confederation Cup]]. African national teams compete in the [[Africa Cup of Nations]] and also in the [[African Nations Championship]] for local teams.
===Ice hockey=== {{main article|Ice hockey in Africa}} Ice hockey is a minority sport in Africa, in which only a handful of African countries participate.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3740911/Tunisia-new-North-African-home-ice-hockey.html |title=Tunisia: the new North African home of ice hockey? |website=Dailymail.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/in-depth/features/cool-runnings-tunisia-s-first-ever-ice-hockey-team-hopes-make-history-sport-olympics-Belgium-563804034 |title=Cool Runnings: Tunisia’s first ever ice hockey team hopes to make history |newspaper=[[Middle East Eye]] |date=2016-07-13 |accessdate=2016-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.africanews.com/2016/08/15/ice-hockey-gaining-ground-in-tunisia/ |title=Ice hockey gaining ground in Tunisia |website=Africanews.com |date=2016-08-15 |accessdate=2016-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=George Kariuki |url=http://cctv-africa.com/2016/07/31/tunisian-team-win-the-first-african-ice-hockey-championship/ |title=Tunisian team win the first African Ice Hockey Championship - CCTV Africa - Strengthening news coverage in Africa |publisher=CCTV Africa |date=2015-11-11 |accessdate=2016-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/montrealer-keen-to-represent-tunisia-in-first-ever-african-ice-hockey-cup-1.3691177 |title=Montrealer keen to represent Tunisia in first-ever African Ice Hockey Cup - Montreal - CBC News |website=Cbc.ca |date=2016-07-23 |accessdate=2016-10-24}}</ref>
===Rugby union=== [[Rugby union]] is popular in [[South Africa]] and other countries as [[Morocco]], [[Namibia]], [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Ivory Coast]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vocativ.com/314566/south-africa-struggles-to-fix-racism-in-sports/|title=South Africa's Struggle To Fix Racism In Sports|date=2 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/21/southafrica-sport-divided-race|title=South African sport still divided by race|first=Ryland|last=Fisher|date=21 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=24 August 2016|via=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kHi7AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA122 |title=Rugby and the South African Nation: Sport, Cultures, Politics, and Power in ... |author1=David Ross Black |author2=David R. Black |author3=John Nauright |page=122 |website=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref> The major competition in the continent is the [[Africa Cup]] that contains the teams in the first level of African rugby, and [[African Development Trophy]] contains the teams in the second level. Only the South Africa rugby team compete in the intercontinental tournament, [[The Rugby Championship]].
===Other sports=== [[Handball]] and [[volleyball]] are popular especially in North Africa, Other team sports like [[water polo]], [[roller hockey]], and [[field hockey]], are also popular in some Eastern and South African countries.
==Individual sports== [[Individual sport]]s are also very important. Africa has a major multisports competition called [[All-Africa Games]] that started in [[1965 All-Africa Games|1965]] held in [[Brazzaville]], [[Republic of the Congo]].
===Athletics=== [[Athletics (track and field)|Athletics]] is one of the major single competitions in Africa. The discipline has been part of the [[Athletics at the African Games|African Games]] since 1965. The [[African Athletics Championships]] has been held biannually since 1979. The [[African Cross Country Championships]] was first held in 1985 and later since 2011. The [[African Mountain Running Championships]] has been held since 2009.
In addition, several editions of the [[IAAF World Cross Country Championships]] have been held in Africa. The [[Meeting International Mohammed VI d'Athlétisme de Rabat]] has been held at Morocco since 2008 as part of the [[IAAF World Challenge]] and the [[IAAF Diamond League]]. Previously, the [[Meeting Grand Prix IAAF de Dakar]] was part of the [[IAAF Grand Prix]] and IAAF World Challenge. The [[Cape Town Marathon]] became a [[IAAF Silver Label]] event in 2014 and a [[IAAF Gold Label]] event in 2017.
[[Kenya at the Olympics|Kenya]] and [[Ethiopia at the Olympics|Ethiopia]] have been dominant in [[athletics at the Summer Olympics]] since the 1960s, especially in mid-distance and long-distance running.
===Cycling=== The [[UCI Africa Tour]] road cycling competition has been held since 2005.
The [[Dimension Data (cycling team)|Dimension Data]], formerly MTN–Qhubeka, was the first African team to enter the Grand Tours in 2015. Notable team members include [[Jacques Janse van Rensburg]] and [[Youcef Reguigui]].
Kenya and Rwanda are rising forces in world cycling.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ben East |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/aug/11/second-chances-rwanda-cycling-lewis-review |title=Land of Second Chances: The Impossible Rise of Rwanda's Cycling Team by Tim Lewis – review | Books |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=2016-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/05/28/world/africa/how-to-cycle-like-a-tour/ |title=Kenya's cycling hero puts next generation on the right track - CNN.com |website=Edition.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/gametheory/2014/09/cycling-eritrea |title=Cycling in Eritrea: Saddled with problems |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |date=2014-09-13 |accessdate=2016-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/dateline/story/lycra-africa-cycling-dream-come-true |title=Lycra in Africa: A cycling dream come true | SBS News |website=Sbs.com.au |date=2015-07-21 |accessdate=2016-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bouchier |first=Tom |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/07/12/sport/cylcing-africa-dimension-data-qhubeka/ |title=Has African cycling arrived? - CNN.com |website=Edition.cnn.com |date=2016-07-12 |accessdate=2016-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/21/sports/cycling/in-country-of-runners-kenyan-cycling-team-faces-uphill-climb.html|title=A Dream on Two Wheels: In Country of Runners, Kenyan Cycling Team Faces Uphill Climb|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|last = Dabbs|first = Brian|date = 20 June 2012|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/eshachhabra/2015/07/10/cycling-becomes-more-inclusive-tour-de-frances-first-africa-team-stands-tall-at-the-podium/#12b28f152ebc |title=Cycling Becomes More Inclusive: Tour de France's First Africa Team Stands Tall at the Podium |website=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-19}}</ref>
===Golf=== Golf is a minority sport in Africa.<ref>{{cite web|last=Smart |first=Tony |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/21/travel/best-golf-courses-africa/ |title=10 best golf courses in Africa - CNN.com |website=Edition.cnn.com |date=2013-07-23 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref> The [[Sunshine Tour]] is based in South Africa but also visits other neighbour countries. Several tournaments have been co-sanctioned by the [[European Tour]], such as the [[South African Open (golf)|South African Open]], [[South African PGA Championship]], [[Alfred Dunhill Championship]], [[Nedbank Golf Challenge]], [[Africa Open]], [[Joburg Open]], [[Tshwane Open]],
Notable African golfers include [[Bobby Locke]], winner of [[The Open Championship|The British Open]] four times in 1949, 1950, 1952 and 1957; [[Gary Player]], winner of the [[The Open Championship|British Open]] in 1959, 1968 and 1974, [[Masters Tournament|The Masters]] in 1961, 1974 and 1978, the [[PGA Championship]] in 1962 and 1972 and the [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S Open]] in 1965; [[Ernie Els]], winner of the [[1994 U.S. Open (golf)|1994]], [[1997 U.S. Open (golf)|1997 U.S. Open]] and [[2002 Open Championship|2002 British Open]]; [[Nick Price]], winner of the 1992 and 1994 [[PGA Championship]] and 1994 British Open; [[Retief Goosen]]; [[Trevor Immelman]]; [[Louis Oosthuizen]] and [[Charl Schwartzel]].
===Tennis===
{{main article|Women's tennis in South Africa}}
[[Tennis]] is minority sport in Africa.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schreiner |first=Tanja |url=http://voicesofafrica.co.za/dreaming-african-tennis-champion/ |title=Dreaming of an African tennis champion |publisher=Voices of Africa |date=2014-02-14 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Gary Morley |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/SPORT/tennis/07/22/tennis.africa.anderson.huber/ |title=What does the future hold for African tennis? - CNN.com |website=Edition.cnn.com |date=2011-07-22 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/26/sports/tennis/african-tennis-players-no-longer-among-worlds-best.html|title=African Tennis Players No Longer Among World's Best|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/video/africa/2014/07/tennis-programme-serves-hope-kenya-slum-20147120623549544.html |title=Tennis programme serves hope in Kenya slum |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2014-07-01 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://africasacountry.com/2015/07/the-story-of-lagos-ill-fated-1976-professional-tennis-tournament/ |title=The story of Lagos’ ill-fated 1976 Professional Tennis Tournament – Africa is a Country |website=Africasacountry.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref>
==Combat sports== There are also major [[martial arts]] and [[combat sport]] competitions in the continent.
===Boxing===
[[Louis Phal]] was the first African world boxing champion. It would another 4 decades for another boxing world champion in the form of [[Richard Ihetu]]. Meanwhile, there was little administrative framework for professional boxing in Africa until 1973, when representatives of nine African nations created the [[African Boxing Union]]. On October 30, 1974, [[Muhammad Ali]] and [[George Foreman]] fought for a heavyweight title in Zaire which became known as [[Rumble in the Jungle]].
Africa has produced many world champions, with [[Azumah Nelson]] the most well known.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FhktPqiJ-PAC&pg=PA115 |title=Sport, Cultures, and Identities in South Africa |author=John Nauright |page=115 |website=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Tim Oates |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/66049-history-of-south-african-sport-ii-boxing |title=History of South African Sport: II. Boxing |publisher=[[Bleacher Report]] |date=2008-10-07 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.supersport.com/boxing/south-africa/news/140113/Africa_has_4_world_champions |title=Africa has 4 ‘world’ champions - SuperSport - Boxing |publisher=SuperSport |date=2016-07-07 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Martin Cuddihy |url=http://thenewdaily.com.au/sport/2016/06/09/muhammad-ali-africa-remembers-boxing-legend/ |title=Africa remembers boxing legend Muhammad Ali |publisher=The New Daily |date=2016-06-09 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hVJYj3RGXjwC&pg=PA574 |title=Why Africa?: A Continent in a Dilemma of Unanswered Questions |author=Bona Udeze |page=574 |website=Books.google.co.uk |date=1967-02-06 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Edward Echwalu |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-05-16-ugandan-women-turn-to-boxing-to-escape-the-slum/ |title=Ugandan women turn to boxing to escape the slum | News | Africa | M&G |website=Mg.co.za |date= |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JRjcAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA47|title=Sport Past and Present in South Africa: (Trans)forming the Nation |author1=Scarlett Cornelissen |author2=Albert Grundlingh |page=47 |website=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IkLYDgTnMxEC&pg=PA109 |title=Sports Around the World: History, Culture, and Practice |page=109 |website=Books.google.co.uk |date=1931-03-23 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref>
===Judo=== Africa has yet to produce a winner in world judo.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shanghaidaily.com/article/article_xinhua.aspx?id=275295 |title=Judo gains popularity as Kenya targets Africa conquest |newspaper=[[Shanghai Daily]] |date=2015-04-01 |accessdate=2016-07-19}}</ref> [[African Judo Championships]] is the most important judo event in Africa.
===Karate=== Karate was first introduced in Africa in the 1960s.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R84DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA44&dq=Karate+South+Africa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=DZB7VITuEMOvaZzpgtgL&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Karate%20South%20Africa&f=false|magazine =Black Belt|title = Splits, Government Suspicion, and Racial Tension |date = May 1966 |publisher=Google Books|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsauthority.com.gh/maincat_select_discipline.cfm?disciplineID=10 |title=National Sports Authority, Ghana |publisher=Sportsauthority.com.gh |date= |accessdate=2015-03-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Resnekov |first=Liam |url=http://fightland.vice.com/blog/love-and-rebellion-how-two-karatekas-fought-apartheid |title=Love and Rebellion: How Two Karatekas Fought Apartheid | FIGHTLAND |publisher=Fightland.vice.com |date=2014-07-16 |accessdate=2015-03-05}}</ref> The [[Union of African Karate Federation]] is charge of karate in Africa.
===Mixed martial arts=== South Africa hosts Extreme Fighting Championship Worldwide (formerly known as EFC Africa).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cagepages.com/2017/07/18/efc-future-mma-resides-africa/|title=EFC: The future of MMA resides in Africa|date=18 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.efcworldwide.com|title=EFC: Extreme Fighting Championship|accessdate=25 April 2013}}</ref> It is the number one [[mixed martial arts]] organisation in the African continent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-04-22-mma-warrior-demarte-pena-still-efc-africas-featherweight-champ/#.V5YmM9KkoT8 |title=MMA warrior, Demarte Pena, still EFC Africa’s featherweight champ |publisher=Daily Maverick |date=2013-04-22 |accessdate=2016-07-25}}</ref>
EFC Africa 01 took place at The [[Coca-Cola Dome]] in Northgate, Johannesburg on 12 November 2009 and is now viewed in 110 [[Country|countries]], including [[United States|USA]], [[Canada]], [[Caribbean|The Caribbean]] and all over [[Europe]]. EFC Africa 19, which was held at Carnival City in Johannesburg on 19 April 2013, topped other African sports ratings with a record of over 1.8 million views with 31.3% of the total South African TV audience ([[South African Broadcasting Corporation|SABC]], [[e.tv]] and [[DStv]] combined). These are the biggest ratings in EFC history, topping EFC Africa 12's record of 1.6 million views and 25.9% audience share.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.efcafrica.com/news/2013/April/efc_africa_news_article_latest_mma_ratings.php|title=EFC Africa: Latest MMA Ratings Smash Other African Sports|accessdate=25 April 2013}}</ref>
===Taekwondo=== Taekwondo is growing as more people compete in the Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|author=Zhang Jingya |url=http://english.cntv.cn/2015/09/13/VIDE1442142361188819.shtml |title=Faces of Africa 09/13/2015 Legacy of a Taekwondo Master Part I - CCTV News - CCTV.com English |website=English.cntv.cn |date= |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.korea.net/NewsFocus/Sports/view?articleId=105461 |title=Taekwondo grows dreams in Africa :: Korea.net : The official website of the Republic of Korea |website=Korea.net |date=2013-02-12 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Emilie Iob |url=http://www.voanews.com/content/ivory-coast-taekwondo-champions-rio-olympics/3405403.html |title=Ivorian Taekwondo Champions Head to Rio Olympics |website=Voanews.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Zhang Jingya |url=http://english.cntv.cn/2015/09/20/VIDE1442744401497543.shtml |title=Faces of Africa 09/20/2015 Legacy of a Taekwondo Master Part 2 |website=English.cntv.cn |accessdate=2016-07-19}}</ref> Africa is emerging as a powerhouse in Taekwondo.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rio2016.com/en/news/africa-emerges-as-new-taekwondo-force-but-korea-reclaim-top-spot|title=Africa emerges as new taekwondo force but Korea reclaim top spot|publisher=|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thenewsnigeria.com.ng/2016/08/rio-olympics-africa-shines-in-taekwondo-as-ivorian-cisse-wins-gold/|title=Rio Olympics: Africa shines in taekwondo as Ivorian Cisse wins gold|date=21 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref> Taekwondo is run by the [[African Taekwondo Union]].
==Winter Olympics==
Many people of the African diaspora represent African nations at the [[Winter Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-43149991|title=Africans at the Winter Olympics: Inspirational - or glory-hunters?|first=Gbolahan Peter|last=Macjob|date=24 February 2018|publisher=|accessdate=8 March 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
==Events== South Africa has hosted the [[1995 Rugby World Cup]], [[2003 Cricket World Cup]] and [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Charles P. Korr |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/2013/12/05/nelson-mandela-death-soccer-rugby-sports-impact-appreciation/2432659/ |title=Nelson Mandela saw sport as way to connect S. Africans |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=2013-12-05 |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/12/05/world/africa/nelson-mandela-sports/ |title=For Nelson Mandela, sports were major weapon against racism |publisher=CNN.com |date=2013-12-06 |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref> Africa has hosted six editions of the [[Pan Arab Games]] and five editions of the [[Mediterranean Games]]. Durban, South Africa was announced as host of the [[2022 Commonwealth Games]] in 2015, but they were denied as hosts in 2017.
Notable continental tournaments are the [[African Games]], [[Africa Cup of Nations]], [[CAF Champions League]], [[African Championships in Athletics]], [[African Rally Championship]] and [[Sunshine Tour]].

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = State Farm Center | nickname = | logo_image = [[File:State Farm Center.svg|250px]] | image = [[File:Assembly-hall-02.jpg|250px]] | location = 1800 South 1st Street
[[Champaign, Illinois|Champaign]], [[Illinois]], United States | coordinates = {{Coord|40.096259|-88.235956|region:US_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = May 25, 1959{{cite news| title=University of Illinois' 'Flying Saucer' Has Aged Gracefully| first=Tom| last=Kacich| url=http://www.news-gazette.com/news/university-illinois/2009-05-20/university-illinois-flying-saucer-has-aged-gracefully.html| newspaper=[[The News-Gazette (Champaign-Urbana)|The News-Gazette]]|location=Champaign| date=May 20, 2009|accessdate=January 22, 2012}} | built = | opened = March 2, 1963 | closed = | demolished = | owner = University of Illinois | operator = University of Illinois | surface = Multi-surface | architect = [[Harrison & Abramovitz]] | structural engineer = [[Ammann & Whitney]] | general_contractor = Felmley-Dickerson Co. | tenants = [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball]] (1963-present)
[[Illinois Fighting Illini women's basketball]] (1974-present) | construction_cost = $8.35 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|8350000|1963}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | former_names = Assembly Hall (1963-2013) | seating_capacity = 4 (permanent), 5 (concert) {{cite web| url=http://www.statefarmcenter.com/arena-info/about-state-farm-center| title=About State Farm Center| publisher=State Farm Center| accessdate=August 28, 2018}} (2016-present)
17,085 (2014-2015)
16,618 (2003-2014)
16,450 (1995-2003)
16,321 (1992-1995)
16,153 (1980-1992)
16,128 (1963-1980) }} '''State Farm Center''', stylized as '''StateFarm Center''', is a large [[dome]]-shaped [[indoor arena]] located in [[Champaign, Illinois]], owned and operated by the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]]. The arena hosts games for the [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball]] and [[Illinois Fighting Illini women's basketball|women's basketball]] teams. It also doubles as a performance and event center, and is one of the largest venues between [[Chicago]] and [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]]. It opened in 1963 and was known until 2013 as '''Assembly Hall''' until [[State Farm Insurance]] acquired [[naming rights]] as part of a major renovation project. ==Opening== {{see also|Construction of Assembly Hall (Champaign)}} State Farm Center opened as Assembly Hall on March 2, 1963, and continues to attract attention for its design and construction. From 1963 to 1965 Assembly Hall was the largest dome structure in North America until the opening of the [[Astrodome]] in [[Houston|Houston, Texas]]. The roof is supported by {{convert|614|mi|km}} of one-quarter inch steel wire wrapped at the base of the dome under intensive pressure. The architect was [[Max Abramovitz]], a University of Illinois alumnus. ==Fighting Illini Basketball== State Farm Center hosts home games of [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball]] and [[Illinois Fighting Illini women's basketball]] and has earned a reputation as one of the toughest places to play in college basketball, thanks to the [[student cheering section]], the "[[Orange Krush]]," which occupies the floor around the court as well as some seats. At the annual "Paint the Hall Orange" game, everyone in attendance would wear an orange shirt, resulting in an impressive and intimidating environment. In recent years, however, it has become customary for Illini fans to wear orange at all home games and so the official "PTHO" game was discontinued after the 2007-08 season. In August 2015, prior to the reopening of the newly renovated State Farm Center, the hardwood floor was dedicated and named '''Lou Henson Court''' in honor of the [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball]] all-time leader in victories [[Lou Henson]].{{cite news| url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/college/ct-lou-henson-court-20150824-story.html| title=Illinois names basketball court for former coach Lou Henson| newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]| date=2015-08-24| accessdate=2015-08-25| last=Ryan| first=Shannon}} ==Men's basketball records at State Farm Center (Assembly Hall)== Kupec]], Michigan...1/2/1975 :Illini player - 13/13, [[Kendall Gill]]...2/8/1990 *'''Most rebounds''' :Overall – 23, [[Joe Franklin (basketball)|Joe Franklin]], [[Wisconsin Badgers men's basketball|Wisconsin]]...12/19/1966 :Illini player – 23, Nick Weatherspoon...3/2/1971 *'''Most assists''' :Illini player – 15, [[Bruce Douglas (basketball)|Bruce Douglas]]...12/14/1985 *'''Most steals''' :Illini player – 7, Kendall Gill...3,4,1990, [[Kenny Battle]]...3/9/1988 & Bruce Douglas...12/8/1986 *'''Most blocks''' :Illini player – 11, [[Derek Holcomb]]...12/8/1978 *'''Most minutes''' :Illini player – 60, Bruce Douglas...1/28/84 {{cite book| url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/ill/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/2014-15/misc_non_event/2014-15_RecordBook.pdf| title=2014-15 Illinois Basketball Record Book| page=137| accessdate=2018-08-28}} ==Size== The third largest [[Illinois]] arena after the [[United Center]] in [[Chicago]] and the [[Allstate Arena]] in [[Rosemont, Illinois|Rosemont]], State Farm Center has 15,500 permanent seats, with an official capacity of 16,618 for basketball games, but when portable chairs are placed on the floor for an in-the-round performance there is a potential for an additional 1,000 depending on the stage configuration. ==IHSA== [[Image:Assembly-hall-01.jpg|thumb|Exterior in 2006]] [[Image:Assembly Hall.jpg|thumb|Exterior in 2003]] State Farm Center has hosted a variety of [[Illinois High School Association]] events. It has been the home of the state individual wrestling tournament since 1967. From 1963 to 1995, State Farm Center played host to the state finals of the boys' basketball tournament. From 1978 to 1995, it also hosted the IHSA girls' basketball tournament. ==Broadway Series== State Farm Center is also the venue for the annual WCIA 3 Broadway Series, which features popular musicals such as ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'', ''[[Miss Saigon]]'', ''[[Rent (musical)|Rent]]'', and ''[[Fiddler on the Roof]]''.{{cite news| title=WCIA 3 Broadway Series not the same old song and dance| url=http://www.news-gazette.com/arts-entertainment/local/2017-03-02/wcia-3-broadway-series-not-same-old-song-and-dance.html| last=Wood| first=Paul| date=March 2, 2017| newspaper=The News-Gazette| accessdate=August 28, 2018}} =="Illinois Renaissance" renovation== In the autumn of 2008, school officials, led by Athletics Director [[Ron Guenther]], conducted a study to decide whether to refurbish the then-named Assembly Hall or build a new basketball arena.{{cite news| title=Guenther Assesses Assembly Hall's Fate| first=Terry| last=Bannon| url=http://chicagosports.chicagotribune.com/sports/college/illinois/cs-080821-illinois-ron-guenther-athletic-director,1,6759120.story| newspaper=Chicago Tribune| date=August 21, 2008| accessdate=August 21, 2008}} In 2010, the university opted to renovate the existing structure and selected the architectural firm [[AECOM]] to design the renovation.{{cite news| title=Board Approves Assembly Hall Architect, Natural History Building Funds and Easter as Interim Vice Chancellor| first=Darshan| last=Patel| url=http://www.dailyillini.com/article_7f45bfa4-a86e-5886-aed8-e126b9284aa5.html| newspaper=[[Daily Illini]]| location=Champaign| date=December 2, 2011| accessdate=December 14, 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725230435/http://www.dailyillini.com/article_7f45bfa4-a86e-5886-aed8-e126b9284aa5.html| archivedate=July 25, 2013|df=}} The athletic department sent surveys to I-Fund and season ticket holders to gauge demand for various premium seating options. Architects used this information to create schematic drawings and architectural renderings near the end of 2012, which then Athletics Director [[Mike Thomas (athletic director)|Mike Thomas]] used to aid in fundraising for the project. The anticipated renovation cost was between $150 and $160 million, and construction would not start before spring of 2014.{{cite news| title=U of I Gauges Demand for Premium Seats in Assembly Hall| first=John| last=Supine| url=http://www.sj-r.com/sports/x1167779048/Illini-Hoops-School-gauges-demand-for-premium-seats-in-Hall| newspaper=[[The State Journal-Register]]| location=Springfield| date=August 14, 2012| accessdate=December 14, 2012}} As part of the renovations, [[State Farm Insurance]] purchased the naming rights to the arena for $60 million over 30 years.{{cite web| title=Illini's Assembly Hall Renamed| agency=[[Associated Press]]| url=http://espn.go.com/chicago/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/9225290/illinois-fighting-illini-assembly-hall-renamed-state-farm-center| website=[[ESPN]]| date=April 29, 2013| accessdate=November 11, 2013}} The State Farm Center began renovations after the 2013–14 men's basketball season. Work included adding luxury suites, club/loge seating, new blue seats included in the renovation. In the luxury suites and club level seats, there will be concessions where alcoholic beverages will allowed to be served as well as a buffet area. The total budget for the renovation was estimated at $169.5 million. The construction process did cause some conflicts with scheduled sporting events at the beginning of the 2015-16 basketball season. The men's basketball team played the first five games of the 2015 at the [[Bank of Springfield Center|Prairie Capital Convention Center]] in [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]], while the 2015 Women's basketball team played their first five games at [[Parkland College]]. The renovated arena hosted its first game on December 2, when the Fighting Illini fell to [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish men's basketball|Notre Dame]] 84–79.{{cite web| title=Frequently Asked Questions| url=http://statefarmcenter.com/faq.html| website=Illinois Division of Intercollegiate Athletics| access-date=2018-08-28| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160219220915/http://statefarmcenter.com/faq.html| archivedate=2016-02-19| df=}} {{cite press release| title=PCCC to host Illini Basketball for 5 games in November 2015| date=October 30, 2014| url=http://www.springfieldpc3.com/news/tabid/125/pccc-to-host-illini-basketball-nov-2015.aspx?TabId=125&PostId=9| publisher=Prairie Capital Convention Center| access-date=2018-08-28}} ===Naming rights=== The following corporate sponsor, Fighting Illini [[Benefactor (law)|benefactors]], former [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball]] players, and [[List of University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign people|University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign alumni]] have donated sizeable contributions towards the $169.5 million renovation cost of the State Farm Center.{{cite press release| url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150116203015/http://www.fightingillini.com/genrel/011515aab.html| publisher=Illinois Division of Intercollegiate Athletics| date=January 15, 2015| accessdate=2018-08-28| title=Former Illini Basketball Great Dave Downey and Family and Friends Make $2 Million SFC Gift| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150116183114/http://www.fightingillini.com/statefarmcenter/news.html| archivedate=2015-01-16| df= }} {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="text-align:center" |- ! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Illinois Fighting Illini|color=#FFFFFF}}; text-align:center" |Donor ! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Illinois Fighting Illini|color=#FFFFFF}}; text-align:center" |Donation ! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Illinois Fighting Illini|color=#FFFFFF}}; text-align:center" |Affiliation ! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Illinois Fighting Illini|color=#FFFFFF}}; text-align:center" |Naming right |- | [[State Farm Insurance]] || $60 million over 30 years || [[Corporate sponsorship]] || ''State Farm Center'' |- | John Giuliani || $5 million || Alumnus || Traditions Club |- | [[Mannie Jackson]] || $3 million || Former player || University of Illinois Basketball Hall of Fame |- | [[Dave Downey]] || $2 million || Former player || Courtside Club |- | Timothy and Sharon Ubben || $2 million || Benefactors || Donor Recognition Wall |- | Jim Benson || $2 million || Alumnus || Legacy Club |- | John Penicook family || $1 million || Alumni || West Horseshoe Drive |- | Phillip and Heidi Sarnecki || $500,000 || Alumni || Men's Coaches Locker Room |- | Dennis D. Swanson family || $500,000 || Alumnus || Illini Media Center |- | H. D. Smith Foundation || $500,000 || Alumnus || Sports Medicine Facility |- | Jeffrey Kautz family || $250,000 || Alumnus || Dining Room |} ==Fighting Illini home courts== *[[Kenney Gym]] (1905–1925) located on the campus of the University of Illinois and is named after Harold E. (Hek) Kenney. The arena opened in 1890 and was originally known as the Men's Gym Annex. *[[Huff Hall]] (1925–1963) opened in 1925 and was known as Huff Gymnasium until the 1990s. It is named after George Huff, who was the school's athletic director from 1895 to 1935. *Assembly Hall/State Farm Center (1963–present) ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{Reflist|refs=}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Assembly Hall (Champaign)|State Farm Center}} * [http://statefarmcenter.com/ Official Site] * [http://www.fightingillini.com/facilities/statefarmcenter.html Illinois DIA Facility Bio] {{University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign campus}} {{Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball navbox}} {{Big Ten Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{Big Ten Conference basketball student section navbox}} {{Illinois NCAA Division I college basketball venue navbox}} {{Music venues of Illinois}} {{Champaign, Illinois}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball venues]] [[Category:Illinois Fighting Illini women's basketball venues]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Illinois]] [[Category:Music venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Professional wrestling venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Wrestling venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Champaign, Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues in Champaign–Urbana, Illinois]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Champaign County, Illinois]] [[Category:Buildings and structures of the University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]] [[Category:Harrison & Abramovitz buildings]] [[Category:1963 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1963]] [[Category:State Farm Insurance]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Talent for the Game | image = Talent for the Game (movie poster).jpg | image size = 220 | alt = | caption = DVD cover | director = [[Robert M. Young (director)|Robert M. Young]] | producer = Martin Elfand | writer = David Himmelstein
Thomas Michael Donnelly
[[Larry Ferguson (screenwriter)|Larry Ferguson]] | narrator = | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Edward James Olmos]] * [[Lorraine Bracco]]}} | music = [[David Newman (composer)|David Newman]] | cinematography = Curtis Clark | editing = Arthur Coburn | studio = | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = April 26, 1991 | runtime = 91 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $336,396{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=talentforthegame.htm|title=Talent for the Game (1991) - Box Office Mojo|website=www.boxofficemojo.com}} | preceded by = | followed by = }} '''''Talent for the Game''''' is a 1991 film directed by [[Robert M. Young (director)|Robert M. Young]] and starring [[Edward James Olmos]], [[Lorraine Bracco]], [[Terry Kinney]], [[Jamey Sheridan]], and Jeff Corbett. The plot concerns a [[baseball]] scout. Scenes were filmed on the [[Palouse]] in the small town of [[Genesee, Idaho|Genesee]], [[Idaho]],{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZZUrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_NAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4198%2C1643622 |newspaper=Idahonian |location=(Moscow) |last=Harriman |first=Peter |title=Our own 'Field of Dreams'|date=July 18, 1990 |page=A1 }}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yZMrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l9AFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5031%2C917245 |newspaper=Idahonian |location=(Moscow) |last=Harriman |first=Peter |title=Talent for 'Americana'|date=August 9, 1990 |page=1A }}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0llYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BPoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5791%2C3810648 |newspaper=Spokane Chronicle |location=(Washington)|agency=Associated Press |title=Cameras will draw a crowd |date=July 30, 1990 |page=A2 }}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GpUrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FdEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3410%2C3534594 |newspaper=Idahonian |location=(Moscow) |agency=Associated Press |title=Palouse baseball movie strikes out in Florida |date=May 25, 1991 |page=A1 }} between [[Lewiston, Idaho|Lewiston]] and [[Moscow, Idaho|Moscow]], and nearby [[Garfield, Washington]]. Other scenes were shot in [[Idaho Panhandle|northern]] Idaho at [[Kellogg, Idaho|Kellogg]].{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2tRYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hfADAAAAIBAJ&pg=2510%2C87372 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington)|last=Webster |first=Dan |title=Casting call |date=August 1, 1990 |page=C1}} After a disappointing debut in a limited number of theaters in Florida, it went quickly to video. ==Plot summary== Virgil Sweet (Olmos) is a veteran baseball scout for the [[California Angels]]. He is in danger of losing his life's work because the Angels' new owner, Gil Lawrence (Kinney), is unhappy with the [[Farm team|farm system]] and threatening to eliminate the team's scouts. Virgil hasn't discovered a great young prospect for quite a while. One day, when the car that he and girlfriend Bobbie (Bracco), who also is employed by the team, are driving breaks down on a rural road, Virgil happens upon a country boy named Sammy Bodeen (Corbett) who has a pitching arm worthy of the [[Major League Baseball|major leagues]]. Greeted back in [[Anaheim]] with considerable skepticism, Virgil arranges a tryout for Sammy. The boy is wild at first and Virgil's great find appears to be a big joke. Once he calms down, however, Sammy proves to have everything it takes to make it big. Team management, desperate for a new star, immediately begins to overplay the arrival of Sammy with wildly overblown hype. A public-relations blitz promotes the boy as baseball's next great star, even though he has yet to throw a pitch in a big-league game. By the time Sammy takes the mound for his first Angels game, expectations are so high that he cannot possibly live up to them. He is roughed up by opponents in the first inning, humiliating the owner and making fans furious. But, gradually, with a surprise assist from Virgil on the field, Sammy settles down and begins to look like a star in the making. ==Cast== {| | * [[Edward James Olmos]] as Virgil Sweet * [[Lorraine Bracco]] as Bobbie * John E. Coleman as Angels Coach * Jeff Corbett as Sammy Bodeen * [[Jamey Sheridan]] as Tim Weaver * [[Terry Kinney]] as Gil Lawrence * Thomas Ryan as Paul * [[Felton Perry]] as Fred * [[Tom Bower (actor)|Tom Bower]] as Rev. Bodeen | * [[Janet Carroll]] as Rachel Bodeen * Daniel A. Haro as Burns * Murphy Sua as Dick Bortner * David Riley as Toby Curry * James Keane as Ray Coffey * Zachary I. Young as Rudy Coffey * [[Dennis Boutsikaris]] as Greg Rossi * [[Leslie Bevis]] as Marla * John Yajko as Riggs{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IjExAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jAgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4706%2C2875256 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington)|last=Johnson |first=Carla K. |title=Man's looks bring him fame |date=August 26, 1990 |page=B2 }} |} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0103036}} *{{Rotten Tomatoes|talent_for_the_game}} {{Robert M. Young}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Talent For The Game}} [[Category:1991 films]] [[Category:1990s sports films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:California Angels]] [[Category:Films shot in Idaho]] [[Category:Films shot in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Films set in Idaho]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert M. Young]] [[Category:Screenplays by Larry Ferguson]] [[Category:Films scored by David Newman]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Townsville Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = Murray Lyons Crescent, [[Annandale, Queensland]], 4814 | coordinates = | broke_ground = 2010 | opened = 2011 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[City of Townsville]] | operator = [[City of Townsville]] | surface = Hardwood | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Townsville Fire]] ([[Women's National Basketball League|WNBL]]) (2011–present)
[[Townsville Crocodiles]] ([[National Basketball League (Australia)|NBL]]) (2014–2015) | seating_capacity = 2,500 |}} The '''Townsville Stadium''' (previously Townsville RSL Stadium) is a multi-purpose indoor venue located at the Murray Sports Complex in [[Annandale, Queensland]]. The facility features an international standard wooden sports floor, multi-purpose function rooms, a public gym, stadium administration and the Townsville City Council.{{cite web|url=https://www.townsville.qld.gov.au/facilities-and-recreation/sport-and-leisure-facilities/townsville-stadium|title=Townsville Stadium|publisher=City of Townsville|accessdate=2016-08-24}} The Stadium, which opened in 2011, is owned and operated by the [[City of Townsville]], has a total spectator capacity of 2,500 (1,700 seated) and is the home court of the [[Townsville Fire]] ([[Women's National Basketball League|WNBL]]). From the [[2014–15 NBL season]], the [[Townsville Crocodiles]] moved out of their long time home, the [[Townsville Entertainment and Convention Centre|Townsville Entertainment Centre]], and into the RSL Stadium. The largest attendance at the venue was recorded on 27 July 2011 for an women's international basketball game when the [[Australian Opals]] played [[China women's national basketball team|China]] in front of 2,200 fans. The Stadium can also host other sports such as [[netball]], [[volleyball]] and [[badminton]], and can also be used for indoor events such as expos, conventions, conferences or dinners. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Townsville Crocodiles}} {{Townsville Fire}} {{NBL Arenas}} {{WNBL Arenas}} [[Category:2011 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Defunct National Basketball League (Australia) venues]] [[Category:Townsville Crocodiles]] [[Category:Townsville Fire]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Townsville]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2011]]

revision.comment: /* Some modern Rogallo flexible-winged aircraft */ Removed wikilink to "Fleep" as a wiki page on Fleep ultralight trikes no longer (or never did?) exist.
revision.text:
{{use mdy dates|date=October 2016}} [[File:AirBorne XT912 Tourer microlight.jpg|400px|thumb|upright=1.14|[[AirBorne XT912 Tourer]]]] [[File:Дельталет 1.jpg|thumbnail|upright=1.14|Ultralight trike in [[Prokhorovka, Belgorod Oblast]]]]
An '''ultralight trike''' is a type of powered [[hang glider]] where flight control is by [[weight-shift control|weight-shift]].<ref>[http://www.faa.gov/regulations_policies/handbooks_manuals/aviation/media/FAA-H-8083-5.pdf Weight-Shift Control Aircraft Flying Handbook]</ref> These [[light-sport aircraft|aircraft]] have a fabric [[Rogallo wing|flex-wing]] from which is suspended a [[tricycle]] fuselage pod driven by a pusher [[Propeller (aeronautics)|propeller]]. The pod accommodates either a solo pilot, or a pilot and a single passenger. Trikes grant affordable, accessible and exciting flying, and have been popular since the 1980s.
Trikes<ref>While many aircraft have tricycle landing gear, the term "trike" refers specifically to the form of aircraft described here.</ref> are referred to as "[[microlight]]s" in Europe. Such aircraft are also known as '''2-axis microlights''', '''flex-wing trikes''', '''weight-shift-control aircraft''',<ref>{{CodeFedReg|14|61|1}}</ref> '''microlight trikes''', '''deltatrikes'''<ref>[http://www.deltatrike.es/ Deltacat ULM AVIATION: deltatrike]</ref> or '''motorized [[deltaplane]]s''',<ref>[http://www.wonderhowto.com/how-to-motorized-deltaplane/ Motorized [[Delta plane]] term]</ref>
== History == [[File:EarlySpratt6.jpg|thumb|'''Dr. George A. Spratt''' towed his hang glider on floats using a motorboat. USA, 1929 [https://web.archive.org/web/20070116080314/http://www.georgespratt.org/docs/EarlySprattAircraft.htm] [https://web.archive.org/web/20070117015324/http://www.georgespratt.org/docs/MoreArticles.htm]]][[File:Paresev in landing.jpg|thumb|right|First towing tests of NASA's [[Paresev]] glider (Para Wing Research Vehicle), March 1962.]] [[File:Barry Hill Palmer (b. 1937).jpg|thumb|right|[[Barry Hill Palmer]], 1961. First hang glider based on Rogallo's flexible wing.]] [[File:Richard Miller.jpeg|thumb|'''Richard Miller''' flying his 'Bamboo Butterfly' hang glider. Vista Del Mar California, 1966.]][[File:MilesFagerlie early hg photo.jpg|thumb|'Standard' flexible-wing hang glider, based on variants of the Rogallo-wing aircraft, 1975.]] {{main|History of hang gliding}} The history of the trike is traced back to the invention of [[Francis Rogallo]]'s flexible wing and subsequent development by the [[Paresev]] engineering team's innovations and then others. On 1948, engineer [[Francis Rogallo]] invented a self-inflating wing which he patented on March 20, 1951,<ref>Article: How ''to Fly Without a Plane'' by Robert Zimmerman, aerospace writer. {{cite web |url=http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/it/1998/4/1998_4_22.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-02-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070301062811/http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/it/1998/4/1998_4_22.shtml |archivedate=March 1, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> as the [[Rogallo wing|Flexible wing]]. It was on October 4, 1957, when the Russian satellite [[Sputnik]] shocked the United States and the space race caught the imagination of its government, causing major increases in U.S. government spending on scientific research, education and on the immediate creation of [[NASA]]. Rogallo was in position to seize the opportunity and released his patent to the government and with his help at the wind tunnels, NASA began a series of experiments testing Rogallo's wing – which was renamed '''Para Wing''' – in order to evaluate it as a recovery system for the Gemini [[space capsule]]s and recovery of used Saturn [[Staged combustion cycle (rocket)|rocket stage]]s.<ref>[https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4308/ch11.htm#382 SPACEFLIGHT REVOLUTION]</ref><ref>On 1965 [[Jack Swigert]], who would later be one of the [[Apollo 13]] astronauts, softly landed a full-scale Gemini capsule using a Para Wing stiffened with inflatable tubes along the wing's edges</ref> F. Rogallo's team adapted and extended the totally flexible principle into semi-rigid variants. This mainly involved stabilizing the leading edges with compressed air beams or rigid structures like aluminum tubes. By 1960, NASA had already made test flights of a powered heavily framed cargo aircraft called the [[Ryan XV-8]] or ''Fleep'' (short for 'Flying Jeep')<ref>The earliest photographic press release of a Rogallo flexible wing in record dates to August 14, 1961, by ''Aviation Week and Space Technology'' magazine.</ref> and by March 1962, of a weight-shift experimental glider called [[Paresev]]. By 1967, all Para Wing projects were dropped by NASA in favor of using round parachutes without officially considering development of personal ultralight gliders, but the airfoil's simplicity of design and ease of construction, along with its capability of slow flight and its gentle landing characteristics, did not go unnoticed by hang glider enthusiasts. The challenge then, was to modify and fit a Rogallo flexible wing with an appropriate frame to allow it to be used as a [[hang glider]].
===Some modern Rogallo flexible-winged aircraft=== A crucial development toward the trike was introduction of several mechanical innovations developed by the [[Paresev]] and the Fleep engineers<!-- Barry Palmer has specified in an interview with Gerard Farell that he was unaware of the Paresev and that his HG was inspired on the Fleep, when published by the Aviation Weekly magazine. -->; they proved the Rogallo wing suitable for free-flight gliding, powered and unpowered, and for safe landing.
Publicity from the [[Ryan XV-8|Fleep]]<ref>Press release of the XV-8 'Fleep': August 14, 1961, by ''Aviation Week and Space Technology'' magazine.</ref> and the [[Paresev]] tests sparked interest in the design among several tinkerers, including [[Barry Hill Palmer|Barry Palmer]], and Sport Aviation of 1962 shown Jim Hobson of Experimental Aircraft Association (wing shown on US national TV in Lawrence Welk Show in 1962). An Australian engineer Mike Burns developed and used the boat-towed Rogallo-airfoiled SkiPlane starting in 1962 through the 1960s. A fellow countryman of Mike Burns, [[John W. Dickenson]], made ski-kites and eventually partnered with Mike Burns to improve the ski-kite; he formatted a ski-kite that used what could be found in the 1929 George A. Spratt simple triangle control bar or A-frame with single-point pendulum weight-shift control.
An influence through John Dickenson's duplication of his device,<ref>[http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_162.htm The Smithsonian National Air & Space Museum'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705184738/http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_162.htm |date=July 5, 2007 }}</ref><ref name="flexwing">Dickenson built a model based on the 'flexile wing' principle with a single hang point on an A-frame: {{cite web |url=http://www.innovated.gov.au/Innovated%5Ccase_studies%5CHang_Glider.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831065553/http://www.innovated.gov.au/Innovated%5Ccase_studies%5CHang_Glider.pdf |archivedate=August 31, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> who named his flexible-wing ski-kite the '''Ski Wing'''.<ref>[http://grafton.nsw.free.fr/ski_wing/ Ski Wing]</ref> Dickenson fashioned a water ski kite [[airframe]] to fit on a Rogallo [[airfoil]]<ref name="flexwing"/><ref>Article by Mark Woodhams, British Columbia Hang Gliding and Paragliding Association: {{cite web |url=http://bchpa.org/newsletter/may04/hghistory.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509154730/http://www.bchpa.org/newsletter/may04/hghistory.htm |archivedate=May 9, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>[http://www.wmof.com/rsw.htm Western Museum of Flight] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602133641/http://www.wmof.com/rsw.htm |date=June 2, 2008 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.auf.asn.au/operations/benchmarks.html The Australian Ultralight Federation – History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001111111/http://www.auf.asn.au/operations/benchmarks.html |date=October 1, 2011 }}</ref> where the pilot sat on a swinging seat while the control frame and wire bracing distributed the load to the wing as well as gave a frame freedom to be pushed/pulled for weight-shift control.<ref>The swinging seat and control frame are two key control elements J. Dickenson 'imported' from ski kites into his successful ''Ski Wing'' kite/hang glider.</ref> Dickenson's Ski Wing turned out to be stable and controllable under tow,<ref>Stability and weight-shift control are flex-wing characteristics previously established and described by its inventor F. Rogallo and by NASA engineers in the [[Paresev]] and [[Fleep]] programs.</ref> unlike the flat manned [[kite]]s used at [[Water skiing|water ski]] shows. The Ski Wing kite was first kited in public at the Grafton Jacaranda Festival in September 1963 by Rod Fuller while towed behind a [[motorboat]]. Australian manufacturers like Bill Bennett<ref>[http://www.moyes.com.au/articledetail.asp?ID=61&Cat=Interest Bill Moyes] Contributions by Bill Bennet as explained by the 'Smithsonian National Air & Space Museum': Delta Wing Phoenix VI {{cite web |url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_phoenix_vib.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819201244/http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_phoenix_vib.htm |archivedate=August 19, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}, Delta Wing Phoenix VI {{cite web |url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_phoenix_vi.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705184528/https://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_phoenix_vi.htm |archivedate=July 5, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}, Delta Wing Phoenix Mariah M-9 {{cite web |url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_M-9.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817203438/http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_M-9.htm |archivedate=August 17, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}, Delta Wing Model 162 {{cite web |url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_162.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705184738/http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_162.htm |archivedate=July 5, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}, Delta Wing Phoenix Viper 175 {{cite web |url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_phoenix_viper.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705184621/https://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_phoenix_viper.htm |archivedate=July 5, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}, Delta Wing Streak 130 {{cite web |url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_130.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118183914/http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/delta_wing_130.htm |archivedate=January 18, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}.</ref> and '''Bill Moyes''',<ref>Moyes's story: [http://www.moyes.com.au/articledetail.asp?ID=41&Cat=], The History of Moyes: [http://www.moyes.com.au/articledetail.asp?ID=61&Cat=]</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/gnt/history/Transcripts/s1227269.htm ABC History – an interview with Moyes]</ref> actively developed and marketed Dickenson's innovations<ref>On October 11, 1963, Dickenson filed for a patent, and a provisional protection was awarded for his application number 36189/63 but the patent was not finally awarded; the claims were not officially reviewed for priority and validity. {{cite web |url=http://www.innovated.gov.au/Innovated%5Ccase_studies%5CHang_Glider.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831065553/http://www.innovated.gov.au/Innovated%5Ccase_studies%5CHang_Glider.pdf |archivedate=August 31, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> to the world, which significantly fueled the hang glider revolution.
Although by the early 1970s many rigid wings were developed, none sold well, while dozens of flexible-wing hang glider companies were springing up worldwide, building variants of Dickenson's Ski Wing. In 1972, [[Popular Mechanics]] and [[Popular Science]] magazines published articles on hang gliding which further increased its popularity,<ref>Hang gliding articles on ''Popular Mechanics'' and ''Popular Science'' magazines: {{cite web |url=http://support.atmos.com/hg/early/early.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-07-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911061815/http://support.atmos.com/hg/early/early.htm |archivedate=September 11, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> as the ''Sky Raiders'' hang gliding movie released in 1975.<ref>The Swallowtail hang glider was featured in the 1976 movie ''Sky Riders'' (filmed in Greece during 1975) starring James Coburn, Robert Culp, Susannah York, and Charles Aznavour. After filming of the action was complete, the Wills Wing team toured Europe and stopped by in England to win the British Championships at Mere, Wiltshire, in August 1975.</ref>
[[Francis Rogallo]], [[Barry Hill Palmer|Barry Palmer]], John Dickenson, and others never made any money out of their innovations.<ref name="flexwing"/><ref>[http://bchpa.org/newsletter/may04/hghistory.htm Article by Mark Woodhams] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509154730/http://www.bchpa.org/newsletter/may04/hghistory.htm |date=May 9, 2008 }}</ref> Profit to manufacturers of hang gliders and Rogallo-winged hang gliders came once organized and insured sporting events grew in popularity. Dickenson's adaptation and innovations eventually produced a foldable hang glider that dramatically reduced difficulty in control, storage, transport, assembly and repair. In addition, the flexible wing lends itself to design changes for possible improvements.
The crucial developments put together by the [[Paresev]] engineers, Barry Palmer, John Dickenson, Bill Bennett, Bill Moyes, Richard Miller, and then hundreds of other innovators gave success to the flexible-wing hang glider.<ref>[http://www.innovated.gov.au/Innovated%5Ccase_studies%5CHang_Glider.pdf "Order of Australia" award for contributions to aviation given in 1996] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831065553/http://www.innovated.gov.au/Innovated%5Ccase_studies%5CHang_Glider.pdf |date=August 31, 2007 }}</ref>
===First trikes=== [[File:XV-8A Fleep Prototype - GPN-2000-001271.jpg|thumb|left|[[Ryan XV-8]] 'Fleep' flown in the Full Scale Tunnel at Langley, 1962]] [[File:PierreAubert.jpg|thumb|left|'''Pierre Aubert''', Switzerland, 1964]]
In 1961, Engineer '''Thomas Purcell''' built a towable Rogallo-wing glider with an aluminum frame, wheels, a seat and basic control rods; soon he replaced the wheels for floats and motorized the aircraft.<ref>[http://www.madehow.com/Volume-5/Hang-Glider.html Thomas Pourcell]</ref> In 1964, Swiss inventor '''Pierre Aubert''' saw a photo of NASA's [[Ryan XV-8|Fleep]] and completed construction of a similar trike. As with the Fleep, his [[Rogallo wing]] was fixed and did not allow for pendulum weight-shift control.<ref>[http://www.trike-expeditions.com/CapeToCape/Olivier_Aubert/OliviersAncestor/oliviersancestor.html Pierre Aubert]</ref>
In March 1967, aeronautical engineer [[Barry Hill Palmer|Barry Palmer]] completed the earliest example of a true weight-shift powered trike: the '''Paraplane''';<ref>[http://members.aol.com/hiitec/kite/trike.html Palmer's trike]</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KrI4qnhL3mE Original video on YouTube]</ref> it was controlled by a single vertical control bar as the [[Paresev]] experimental glider that inspired him. The Paraplane used two ''West Bend-Chrysler'' 820 engines of 8 hp at 6000 RPM, reduced to 4700 RPM for about 6.5 hp each, for a total of 13 hp. Each engine had a direct drive to a 27-inch-diameter two-blade propeller made of polyester and fiberglass. On March 24, 1967, Palmer registered the trike with the [[FAA]] as the ''Palmer Parawing D-6'', serial number 1A, registration number N7144; no restrictions were noted.
The second Palmer trike, '''Skyhook''' (FAA registration N4411), in spite of its early date of origin, had most of the attributes of a modern ultralight, except it used a single-cylinder [[snowmobile]] engine, as the two-stroke twin-cylinder engines were not available yet. It was powered by a 17 hp at 5000 RPM single-cylinder JLO L297 two-stroke engine, driving a composite propeller designed and built by Palmer himself and driven by a 2.1/1 reduction gearbox. The engine had electric start and the craft had fiberglass composite spring landing gear. Airframe construction was bolted 6061-T6 aluminum thin-wall tube, with 6061 T-6 extruded angle. The craft took off, flew, and landed at around 30 mph.<ref>[http://members.aol.com/hiitec/kite/trike.html Palmer's web site]</ref>
The commercial availability of Dickenson's hang glider made the [[Rogallo wing]] very popular, and prompted several builders during the 1970s to attempt motorization of their flexible-wing aircraft<ref>[http://perso.orange.fr/pulma1/Un%20peu%20d'histoire.htm Some early powered hang gliders]</ref> but unlike [[Barry Hill Palmer|Barry Palmer]] – who placed the center of gravity well below the keel – most builders were mounting the engine to the wing, where a fine balance existed between applying too much power, causing the aircraft to overtake the pilot, or not enough power for flight. It was not until Roland Magallon took a long look at the ''Motodelta'' ultralight<ref>[http://golfo1.free.fr/historique_pendulaire.htm Motodelta – images]</ref> (a hybrid Rogallo wing designed by Jean-Marc Geiser had a 'fuselage' and a rudder) that Magallon decided to replace the Motodelta's 'fuselage' with a simple tubular framework pendulum and dispensing with the [[rudder]].<ref>[http://www.bmaa.org/histdets.asp?HistoryID=6 Rolland Magallon] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807184715/http://www.bmaa.org/histdets.asp?HistoryID=6 |date=August 7, 2007 }}</ref> Magallon is thus generally thought to have invented the trike because it was he who first marketed it. He called the first version 'Mosquito' and marketed it from October 1979 through 1981. The prototype had flown with a [[McCulloch MC-101A]] motor of 125 cc, delivering 10 hp at 8000 RPM to a direct-drive prop with ground-adjustable pitch. Later he offered it with a [[Solo 210]] engine which produced {{convert|15|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at much smaller RPM.<ref>[http://www.bmaa.org/histdets.asp?HistoryID=6 Roland Magallon's trike] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807184715/http://www.bmaa.org/histdets.asp?HistoryID=6 |date=August 7, 2007 }}</ref>
The "trike", as it soon became known, quickly became popular in the [[UK]] and [[France]], where it had been reborn. Trike technology still shows its hang gliding origins, though the wings are no longer converted hang gliders, but are designed for power. In fact, none of the commercially available trike wings can be used as foot-launched hang gliders as they are too heavy and too fast.<ref>[http://www.aerialpursuits.com/trikes/primer.htm ''Aerial Pursuits'']</ref>
== Manufacturers == Many trike manufacturers produce only the undercarriage and procure their wings elsewhere. The majority of these companies are found in [[Europe]], with a number appearing in the [[United States]]. Manufacturers can also be found in [[India]], [[South Africa]], [[Australia]], and elsewhere. At their most basic, manufacturers often sell single-place ultralight trikes at a price of around $10,000–$17,000<ref>[http://ultralight-airplanes.info/How-To-Fly-Easier-With-Flex-Wing-Ultralight-Aircraft-%28Ultralight-Trikes%29.html UL trikes general pricing]</ref> Prices often depend on whether the wing is included. Two-person, high-performance trikes may cost from $15,000–$30,000 and up. For instance, the two-seater [[Air Creation Tanarg]] can cost up to $85,000 when loaded with every available performance option.<ref>[http://elitechoice.org/2009/02/22/tanarg-will-let-you-touch-the-skies/ Tanarg Pricing]</ref>
== Records == [[Brian Milton]] flew from London to Sydney in 1987 in the Dalgety flyer which at the time was the longest recorded microlight flight taking 59 days. The Dalgety Flyer is now on display at [[Sydney Airport]]. In 1998, he made the first circumnavigation of the world by ultralight, completing the flight in 80 flying days (over a period of 120 days) in the Global Flyer, a [[Pegasus Quantum]], including crossing the Alps and being buzzed by a Syrian MiG, setting a [[Guinness World Record]] for the first and fastest ultralight circumnavigation of the world and resulting in the award of both the [[Britannia Trophy]] and the [[Segrave Trophy]].
On January 19, 2008, Mark Jackson from [[Altrincham]], [[UK]], flew over [[Kilimanjaro]]. In doing so, he broke the record for the highest altitude attained in a microlight, {{convert|24262|ft|m}}, and the fastest climb to {{convert|20000|ft|m}} (25 minutes). He also broke the British record for the fastest climb to {{convert|10000|ft|m}} (19 minutes). He did the flight with Eve Jackson.<ref>[http://menmedia.co.uk/news/s/1051786_a_microlight_fantastic MEN news]</ref>
== See also == {{Commons category|Ultralight trikes}} * [[Paragliding]] * [[Hang gliding]] * [[Powered hang glider]] * [[Powered paraglider]] * [[Ultralight aviation]] * [[Ultralight aircraft (United States)]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Ultralight aircraft]] [[Category:Air sports]] [[Category:Ultralight trikes| ]]

[[Loves Park, IL]] 61111 | coordinates = {{Coord|42.3247|N|89.0273|W|region:US-IL_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | built = | opened = 2007 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Andres Robles | operator = | surface = Field Turf | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Chicago Knights]] ([[Continental Indoor Football League|CIFL]]) (2011)
